SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Iuſtice Shallow, Slender, Sir Hugh Euans, Maſter Page, Falstoffe, Bardolph, Nym, Piſtoll, Anne Page, Miſtreſſe Ford, Miſtreſſe Page, Simple.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shallow.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Hugh, perſwade me not: I will make a Star-
Chamber matter of it, if hee were twenty Sir
Iohn Falſtoffs, he ſhall not abuſe Robert Shallow
Eſquire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: In the County of Gloceſter, Iuſtice of Peace and Coram.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: I (Coſen Slender) and Cuſt-alorum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and Rato lorum too; and a Gentleman borne
(Maſter Parſon) who writes himſelfe Armigero, in any
Bill, Warrant, Quittance, or Obligation, Armigero.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: I that I doe, and haue done any time theſe three
hundred yeeres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: All his ſucceſſors (gone before him) hath don’t:
and all his Anceſtors (that come after him) may: they
may giue the dozen white Luces in their Coate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: It is an olde Coate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: The dozen white Lowſes doe become an old
Coat well: it agrees well paſſant: It is a familiar beaſt to
man, and ſignifies Loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: The Luſe is the freſh-fiſh, the ſalt-fiſh, is an old
Coate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I may quarter (Coz).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: You may, by marrying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: It is marring indeed, if he quarter it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Not a whit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes per-lady: if he ha’s a quarter of your coat,
there is but three Skirts for your ſelfe, in my ſimple con-
ieƈtures; but that is all one: if Sir Iohn Falſtaffe haue
committed diſparagements vnto you, I am of the Church
and will be glad to do my beneuolence, to make attone-
ments and compremiſes betweene you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: The Councell ſhall heare it, it is a Riot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: It is not meet the Councell heare a Riot: there
is no feare of Got in a Riot: The Councell (looke you)
ſhall deſire to heare the feare of Got, and not to heare a
Riot: take your viza-ments in that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha; o’ my life, if I were yong againe, the ſword
ſhould end it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: It is petter that friends is the ſword, and end
it: and there is alſo another deuice in my praine, which
peraduenture prings goot diſcretions with it. There is
Anne Page, which is daughter to Maſter Thomas Page,
which is pretty virginity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Miſtris Anne Page? ſhe has browne haire, and
ſpeakes ſmall like a woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: It is that ferry perſon for all the orld, as iuſt as
you will deſire, and ſeuen hundred pounds of Moneyes,
and Gold, and Siluer, is her Grand-ſire vpon his deaths-
bed, (Got deliuer to a ioyfull resurreƈtions) giue, when
ſhe is able to ouertake ſeuenteene yeeres old. It were a
goot motion, if we leaue our pribbles and prabbles, and
deſire a marriage betweene Maſter Abraham, and Miſtris
Anne Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Did her Grand-ſire leaue her ſeauen hundred
pound?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and her father is make her a petter penny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I know the young Gentlewoman, ſhe has good
gifts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Seuen hundred pounds, and poſſibilities, is
goot gifts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Wel, let vs ſee honeſt Mr Page: is Falſtaffe there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I tell you a lye? I doe deſpiſe a lyer, as I
doe deſpiſe one that is falſe, or as I deſpiſe one that is not
true: the Knight Sir Iohn is there, and I beſeech you be
ruled by your well-willers: I will peat the doore for Mr.
Page. What hoa? Got-pleſſe your houſe heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mr.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Who’s there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Here is go’t’s pleſſing and your friend, and Iu-
ſtice Shallow, and heere yong Maſter Slender: that perad-
uentures ſhall tell you another tale, if matters grow to
your likings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mr.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad to ſee your Worſhips well: I
thanke you for my Veniſon Maſter Shallow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Maſter Page, I am glad to ſee you: much good
doe it your good heart: I wiſh’d your Veniſon better, it
was ill killd: how doth good Miſtreſſe Page? and I thank
you alwaies with my heart, la: with my heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I thanke you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I thanke you: by yea, and no I doe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad to ſee you, good Maſter Slender.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: How do’s your fallow Greyhound, Sir, I heard
ſay he was out-run on Cotſall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: It could not be iudg’d, Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: You’ll not confeſſe: you’ll not confeſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: That he will not, ‘tis your fault, ‘tis your fault:
‘tis a good dogge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: A Cur, Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir: hee’s a good dog, and a faire dog, can there
be more ſaid? he is good, and faire. Is Sir Iohn Falſtaffe
heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, hee is within: and I would I could doe a
good office betweene you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: It is ſpoke as a Chriſtians ought to ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath wrong’d me (Maſter Page.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, he doth in ſome ſort confeſſe it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: If it be confeſſed, it is not redreſſed; is not that
ſo (M. Page?) he hath wrong’d me, indeed he hath, at a
word he hath: beleeue me, Robert Shallow Eſquire, ſaith
he is wronged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ma.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: Here comes Sir Iohn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Now, Maſter Shallow, you’ll complaine of me to
the King?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Knight, you haue beaten my men, kill’d my
deere, and broke open my Lodge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: But not kiſs’d your Keepers daughter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Tut, a pin: this ſhall be anſwer’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I will anſwere it ſtrait, I haue done all this:
That is now anſwer’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: The Councell ſhall know this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Twere better for you if it were known in coun-
cell: you’ll be laugh’d at.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: Pauca verba; (Sir Iohn) good worts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Good worts? good Cabidge; Slender, I broke
your head: what matter haue you againſt me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry ſir, I haue matter in my head againſt you,
and againſt your cony-catching Raſcalls, Bardolf, Nym,
and Piſtoll.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: You Banbery Cheeſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I, it is no matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, Mephoſtophilus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I, it is no matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nym.
SPEECH.LINE: Slice, I ſay; pauca, pauca: Slice, that’s my humor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Where’s Simple my man? can you tell, Coſen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, I pray you: now let vs vnderſtand: there
is three Vmpires in this matter, as I vnderſtand; that is,
Maſter Page (fidelicet Maſter Page,) & there is my ſelfe,
(fidelicet my ſelfe) and the three party is (laſtly, and fi-
nally) mine Hoſt of the Gater.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ma.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: We three to hear it, & end it between them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Ferry goo’t, I will make a priefe of it in my
note-booke, and we wil afterwards orke vpon the cauſe,
with as great diſcreetly as we can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Piſtoll.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: He heares with eares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: The Teuill and his Tam: what phraſe is this?
he heares with eare? why, it is affeƈtations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Piſtoll, did you picke M. Slenders purſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I, by theſe gloues did hee, or I would I might
neuer come in mine owne great chamber againe elſe, of
ſeauen groates in mill-ſixpences, and two Edward Sho-
uelboords, that coſt me two ſhilling and two pence a
peece of Yead Miller: by theſe gloues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Is this true, Piſtoll?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: No, it is falſe, if it is a picke-purſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha, thou mountaine Forreyner: Sir Iohn, and
Maſter mine, I combat challenge of this Latine Bilboe:
word of deniall in thy labras here; word of denial; froth,
and ſcum thou lieſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: By theſe gloues, then ‘twas he.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nym.
SPEECH.LINE: Be auis’d ſir, and paſſe good humours: I will
ſay marry trap with you, if you runne the nut-hooks hu-
mor on me, that is the very note of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: By this hat, then he in the red face had it: for
though I cannot remember what I did when you made
me drunke, yet I am not altogether an aſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſay you Scarlet, and Iohn?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſir, (for my part) I ſay the Gentleman had
drunke himſelfe out of his fiue ſentences.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: It is his fiue ſences: fie, what the ignorance is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: And being fap, ſir, was (as they ſay) caſheerd: and
ſo concluſions paſt the Car-eires.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I, you ſpake in Latten then to: but ‘tis no mat-
ter; Ile nere be drunk whilſt I liue againe, but in honeſt,
ciuill, godly company for this tricke: if I be drunke, Ile
be drunke with thoſe that haue the feare of God, and not
with drunken knaues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: So got-udge me, that is a vertuous minde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: You heare all theſe matters deni’d, Gentlemen;
you heare it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mr.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay daughter, carry the wine in, wee’ll
drinke within.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh heauen: This is Miſtreſſe Anne Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mr.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Miſtris Ford?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Miſtris Ford, by my troth you are very wel met:
by your leaue good Miſtris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mr.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Wife, bid theſe gentlemen welcome: come,
we haue a hot Veniſon paſty to dinner; Come gentle-
men, I hope we ſhall drinke downe all vnkindneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I had rather then forty ſhillings I had my booke
of Songs and Sonnets heere: How now Simple, where
haue you beene? I muſt wait on my ſelfe, muſt I? you
haue not the booke of Riddles about you, haue you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim.
SPEECH.LINE: Booke of Riddles? why did you not lend it to
Alice Short-cake vpon Alhallowmas laſt, a fortnight a-
fore Michaelmas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Come Coz, come Coz, we ſtay for you: a word
with you Coz: marry this, Coz: there is as ‘twere a ten-
der, a kinde of tender, made a farre-off by Sir Hugh here:
doe you vnderſtand me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I Sir, you ſhall finde me reaſonable; if it be ſo,
I ſhall doe that that is reaſon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but vnderſtand me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: So I doe Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue eare to his motions; (Mr. Slender) I will
deſcription the matter to you, if you be capacity of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I will doe as my Cozen Shallow ſaies: I
pray you pardon me, he’s a Iuſtice of Peace in his Coun-
trie, ſimple though I ſtand here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: But that is not the queſtion: the queſtion is
concerning your marriage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: I, there’s the point Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry is it: the very point of it, to Mi. An Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Why if it be ſo; I will marry her vpon any rea-
ſonable demands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: But can you affeƈtion the ‘o-man, let vs command
to know that of your mouth, or of your lips: for diuers
Philoſophers hold, that the lips is parcell of the mouth:
therfore preciſely, cá you carry your good wil to ý maid?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sh.
SPEECH.LINE: Coſen Abraham Slender, can you loue her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I hope ſir, I will do as it ſhall become one that
would doe reaſon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, got’s Lords, and his Ladies, you muſt ſpeake
poſſitable, if you can carry-her your deſires towards her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: That you muſt:
Will you, (vpon good dowry) marry her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I will doe a greater thing then that, vpon your
requeſt (Coſen) in any reaſon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay conceiue me, conceiue mee, (ſweet Coz):
what I doe is to pleaſure you (Coz:) can you loue the
maid?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I will marry her (Sir) at your requeſt; but if
there bee no great loue in the beginning, yet Heauen
may decreaſe it vpon better acquaintance, when wee
are married, and haue more occaſion to know one ano-
ther: I hope vpon familiarity will grow more content:
but if you ſay mary-her, I will mary-her, that I am freely
diſſolued, and diſſolutely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: It is a fery diſcretion-anſwere; ſaue the fall is in
the ‘ord, diſſolutely: the ort is (according to our mea-
ning) reſolutely: his meaning is good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sh.
SPEECH.LINE: I: I thinke my Coſen meant well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: I, or elſe I would I might be hang’d (la.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sh.
SPEECH.LINE: Here comes faire Miſtris Anne; would I were
yong for your ſake, Miſtris Anne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: The dinner is on the Table, my Father deſires
your worſhips company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sh.
SPEECH.LINE: I will wait on him, (faire Miſtris Anne.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: Od’s pleſſed-wil: I wil not be abſéce at the grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: Wil’t pleaſe your worſhip to come in, Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: No, I thank you forſooth, hartely; I am very well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: The dinner attends you, Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: I am not a-hungry, I thanke you, forſooth: goe,
Sirha, for all you are my man, goe wait vpon my Coſen
Shallow: a Iuſtice of peace ſometime may be beholding
to his friend, for a Man; I keepe but three Men, and a
Boy yet, till my Mother be dead: but what though, yet
I liue like a poore Gentleman borne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: I may not goe in without your worſhip: they
will not ſit till you come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: I’faith, ile eate nothing: I thanke you as much as
though I did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you Sir walke in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: I had rather walke here (I thanke you) I bruiz’d
my ſhin th’ other day, with playing at Sword and Dag-
ger with a Maſter of Fence (three veneys for a diſh of
ſtew’d Prunes) and by my troth, I cannot abide the ſmell
of hot meate ſince. Why doe your dogs barke ſo? be
there Beares ith’ Towne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke there are, Sir, I heard them talk’d of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: I loue the ſport well, but I ſhall as ſoone quarrell
at it, as any man in England: you are afraid if you ſee the
Beare looſe, are you not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: I indeede Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s meate and drinke to me now: I haue ſeene
Sackerſon looſe, twenty times, and haue taken him by the
Chaine: but (I warrant you) the women haue ſo cride
and ſhrekt at it, that it paſt: But women indeede, cannot
abide ‘em, they are very ill-fauour’d rough things.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ma.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, gentle M. Slender, come; we ſtay for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile eate nothing, I thanke you Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ma.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: By cocke and pie, you ſhall not chooſe, Sir:
come, come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, pray you lead the way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ma.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on, Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: Miſtris Anne: your ſelfe ſhall goe firſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: Not I Sir, pray you keepe on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: Truely I will not goe firſt: truely-la: I will not
doe you that wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sl.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile rather be vnmannerly, then troubleſome: you
doe your ſelfe wrong indeede-la.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: Go your waies, and aske of Doƈtor Caius houſe,
which is the way; and there dwels one Miſtris Quickly;
which is in the manner of his Nurſe; or his dry-Nurſe; or
his Cooke; or his Laundry; his Waſher, and his Ringer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Si.
SPEECH.LINE: Well Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, it is petter yet: giue her this letter; for it is
a ‘oman that altogeathers acquaintáce with Miſtris Anne
Page; and the Letter is to deſire, and require her to ſoli-
cite your Maſters deſires, to Miſtris Anne Page: I pray
you be gon: I will make an end of my dinner; ther’s Pip-
pins and Cheeſe to come.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Falſtaffe, Hoſt, Bardolfe, Nym, Piſtoll, Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Mine Hoſt of the Garter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſaies my Bully Rooke? ſpeake ſchollerly,
and wiſely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Truely mine Hoſt; I muſt turne away ſome of my
followers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: Diſcard, (bully Hercules) caſheere; let them wag;
trot, trot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſit at ten pounds a weeke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou’rt an Emperor (Ceſar, Keiſer and Pheazar)
I will entertaine Bardolfe: he ſhall draw; he ſhall tap; ſaid
I well (bully Heƈtor?)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fa.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe ſo (good mine Hoſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ho.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue ſpoke; let him follow; let me ſee thee froth,
and liue: I am at a word: follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Bardolfe, follow him: a Tapſter is a good trade:
an old Cloake, makes a new Ierkin: a wither’d Seruing-
man, a freſh Tapſter: goe, adew.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ba.
SPEECH.LINE: It is a life that I haue deſir’d: I will thriue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: O baſe hungarian wight: wilt ӳ the ſpigot wield.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ni.
SPEECH.LINE: He was gotten in drink: is not the humor cóceited?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad I am ſo acquit of this Tinderbox: his
Thefts were too open: his filching was like an vnskilfull
Singer, he kept not time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ni.
SPEECH.LINE: The good humor is to ſteale at a minutes reſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Conuay: the wiſe it call: Steale? foh: a fico for
the phraſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſirs, I am almoſt out at heeles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then let Kibes enſue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: There is no remedy: I muſt conicatch, I muſt ſhift.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Yong Rauens muſt haue foode.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Which of you know Ford of this Towne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: I ken the wight: he is of ſubſtance good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: My honeſt Lads, I will tell you what I am about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Two yards, and more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: No quips now Piſtoll: (Indeede I am in the waſte
two yards about: but I am now about no waſte: I am a-
bout thrift) briefely: I doe meane to make loue to Fords
wife: I ſpie entertainment in her: ſhee diſcourſes: ſhee
carues: ſhe giues the leere of inuitation: I can conſtrue
the aƈtion of her familier ſtile, & the hardeſt voice of her
behauior (to be engliſh’d rightly) is, I am Sir Iohn Falſtafs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath ſtudied her will; and tranſlated her will:
out of honeſty, into Engliſh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ni.
SPEECH.LINE: The Anchor is deepe: will that humor paſſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Now, the report goes, ſhe has all the rule of her
husbands Purſe: he hath a legend of Angels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: As many diuels entertaine: and to her Boy ſay I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ni.
SPEECH.LINE: The humor riſes: it is good: humor me the angels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue writ me here a letter to her: & here ano-
ther to Pages wife, who euen now gaue mee good eyes
too; examind my parts with moſt iudicious illiads: ſome-
times the beame of her view, guilded my foote: ſome-
times my portly belly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Then did the Sun on dung-hill ſhine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ni.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke thee for that humour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſhe did ſo courſe o’re my exteriors with ſuch
a greedy intention, that the appetite of her eye, did ſeeme
to ſcorch me vp like a burning-glaſſe: here’s another
letter to her: She beares the Purſe too: She is a Region
in Guiana: all gold, and bountie: I will be Cheaters to
them both, and they ſhall be Exchequers to mee: they
ſhall be my Eaſt and Weſt Indies, and I will trade to
them both: Goe, beare thou this Letter to Miſtris Page;
and thou this to Miſtris Ford: we will thriue (Lads) we
will thriue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I Sir Pandarus of Troy become,
And by my ſide weare Steele? then Lucifer take all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ni.
SPEECH.LINE: I will run no baſe humor: here take the humor-
Letter; I will keepe the hauior of reputation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Hold Sirha, beare you theſe Letters tightly,
Saile like my Pinnaſſe to theſe golden ſhores.
Rogues, hence, auaunt, vaniſh like haile-stones; goe,
Trudge; plod away ith’ hoofe: ſeeke ſhelter, packe:
Falſtaffe will learne the honor of the age,
French-thrift, you Rogues, my ſelfe, and ſkirted Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Let Vultures gripe thy guts: for gourd, and
Fullam holds: & high and low beguiles the rich & poore,
Teſter ile haue in pouch when thou ſhalt lacke,
Baſe Phrygian Turke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ni.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue opperations,
Which be humors of reuenge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt thou reuenge?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ni.
SPEECH.LINE: By Welkin, and her Star.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: With wit, or Steele?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ni.
SPEECH.LINE: With both the humors, I:
I will diſcuſſe the humour of this Loue to Ford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: And I to Page ſhall eke vnfold
How Falſtaffe (varlet vile)
His Doue will proue; his gold will hold,
And his ſoft couch defile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ni.
SPEECH.LINE: My humour ſhall not coole: I will incenſe Ford
to deale with poyſon: I will poſſeſſe him with yallow-
neſſe, for the reuolt of mine is dangerous: that is my
true humour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art the Mars of Malecontents: I ſecond
thee: troope on.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Miſtris Quickly, Simple, Iohn Rugby, Doƈtor, Caius, Fenton.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: What, Iohn Rugby, I pray thee goe to the Caſe-
ment, and ſee if you can ſee my Maſter, Maſter Doƈter
Caius comming: if he doe (I’ faith) and finde any body
in the houſe; here will be an old abuſing of Gods pati-
ence, and the Kings Engliſh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ru.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile goe watch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe, and we’ll haue a poſſet for’t ſoone at night,
(in faith) at the latter end of a Sea-cole-fire: An honeſt,
willing, kinde fellow, as euer ſeruant ſhall come in houſe
withall: and I warrant you, no tel-tale, nor no breede-
bate: his worſt fault is, that he is giuen to prayer; hee is
ſomething peeuiſh that way: but no body but has his
fault: but let that paſſe. Peter Simple, you ſay your
name is?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Si.
SPEECH.LINE: I: for fault of a better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: And Maſter Slender’s your Maſter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Si.
SPEECH.LINE: I forſooth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Do’s he not weare a great round Beard, like a
Glouers pairing-knife?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Si.
SPEECH.LINE: No forſooth: he hath but a little wee-face; with
a little yellow Beard: a Caine colourd Beard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: A ſoftly-sprighted man, is he not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Si.
SPEECH.LINE: I forſooth: but he is as tall a man of his hands, as
any is betweene this and his head: he hath fought with
a Warrener.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: How ſay you: oh, I ſhould remember him: do’s
he not hold vp his head (as it were?) and ſtrut in his gate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Si.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes indeede do’s he.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, heauen ſend Anne Page, no worſe fortune:
Tell Maſter Parſon Euans, I will doe what I can for your
Maſter: Anne is a good girle, and I wiſh—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ru.
SPEECH.LINE: Out alas: here comes my Maſter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: We ſhall all be ſhent: Run in here, good young
man: goe into this Cloſſet: he will not ſtay long: what
Iohn Rugby? Iohn: what Iohn I ſay? goe Iohn, goe en-
quire for my Maſter, I doubt he be not well, that hee
comes not home: (and downe, downe, adowne’a. &c.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: Vat is you ſing? I doe not like des-toyes: pray
you goe and vetch me in my Cloſſet, vnboyteene verd;
a Box, a greene-a-Box: do intend vat I ſpeake? a greene-
a-Box.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: I forſooth ile fetch it you:
I am glad hee went not in himſelfe: if he had found the
yong man he would haue bin horne-mad.

LINE.ITALIC: Fe, fe, fe, fe, mai foy, il fait for ehando, Ie man voi a le

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it this Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.

LINE.ITALIC: Ouy mette le au mon pocket, de-peech quickly:

SPEECH.LINE: Vere is dat knaue Rugby?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: What Iohn Rugby, Iohn?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ru.
SPEECH.LINE: Here Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: You are Iohn Rugby, aad you are Iacke Rugby:
Come, take-a-your Rapier, and come after my heele to
the Court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ru.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis ready Sir, here in the Porch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: By my trot: I tarry too long: od’s-me: que ay ie
oublie: dere is ſome Simples in my Cloſſet, dat I vill not
for the varld I ſhall leaue behinde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay-me, he’ll finde the yong man there, & be mad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: O Diable, Diable: vat is in my Cloſſet?
Villanie, La-roone: Rugby, my Rapier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Maſter be content.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore ſhall I be content-a?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: The yong man is an honeſt man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhall de honeſt man do in my Cloſſet: dere
is no honeſt man dat ſhall come in my Cloſſet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: I beſeech you be not ſo flegmaticke: heare the
truth of it. He came of an errand to mee, from Parſon
Hugh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: Vell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Si.
SPEECH.LINE: I forſooth: to desire her to—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, I pray you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace-a-your tongue: ſpeake-a-your Tale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Si.
SPEECH.LINE: To deſire this honeſt Gentlewoman (your Maid)
to ſpeake a good word to Miſtris Anne Page, for my Ma-
ſter in the way of Marriage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: This is all indeede-la: but ile nere put my finger
in the fire, and neede not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Hugh ſend-a you? Rugby, ballow mee ſome
paper: tarry you a littell-a-while.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad he is ſo quiet: if he had bin through-
ly moued, you ſhould haue heard him ſo loud, and ſo me-
lancholly: but notwithſtanding man, Ile doe yoe your
Maſter what good I can: and the very yea, & the no is, ý
French Doƈtor my Maſter, (I may call him my Maſter,
looke you, for I keepe his houſe; and I waſh, ring, brew,
bake, ſcowre, dreſſe meat and drinke, make the beds, and
doe all my ſelfe.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simp.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis a great charge to come vnder one bodies
hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you a-uis’d o’that? you ſhall finde it a great
charge: and to be vp early, and down late: but notwith-
ſtanding, (to tell you in your eare, I wold haue no words
of it) my Maſter himſelfe is in loue with Miſtris Anne
Page: but notwithſtanding that I know Ans mind, that’s
neither heere nor there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caius.
SPEECH.LINE: You, Iack’Nape: giue-‘a this Letter to Sir
Hugh, by gar it is a ſhallenge: I will cut his troat in de
Parke, and I will teach a ſcuruy Iack-a-nape Prieſt to
meddle, or make:— you may be gon: it is not good
you tarry here: by gar I will cut all his two ſtones: by
gar, he ſhall not haue a ſtone to throw at his dogge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas: he ſpeakes but for his friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caius.
SPEECH.LINE: It is no matter ‘a ver dat: do not you tell-a-me
dat I ſhall haue Anne Page for my ſelfe? by gar, I vill
kill de Iack-Prieſt: and I haue appointed mine Hoſt of
de Iarteer to meaſure our weapon: by gar, I wil my ſelfe
haue Anne Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, the maid loues you, and all ſhall bee well:
We muſt giue folkes leaue to prate: what the good-ier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caius.
SPEECH.LINE: Rugby, come to the Court with me: by gar, if
I haue not Anne Page, I ſhall turne your head out of my
dore: follow my heeles, Rugby.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall haue An-fooles head of your owne:
No, I know Ans mind for that: neuer a woman in Wind-
sor knowes more of Ans minde then I doe, nor can doe
more then I doe with her, I thanke heauen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fenton.
SPEECH.LINE: Who’s with in there, hoa?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Who’s there, I troa? Come neere the houſe I
pray you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: How now (good woman) how doſt thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: The better that it pleaſes your good Worſhip
to aske?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: What newes? how do’s pretty Miſtris Anne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: In truth Sir, and ſhee is pretty, and honeſt, and
gentle, and one that is your friend, I can tell you that by
the way, I praiſe heauen for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I doe any good thinkſt thou? ſhall I not
looſe my ſuit?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Troth Sir, all is in his hands aboue: but not-
withſtanding (Maſter Fenton) Ile be ſworne on a booke
ſhee loues you: haue not your Worſhip a wart aboue
your eye?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes marry haue I, what of that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Wel, thereby hangs a tale: good faith, it is ſuch
another Nan; (but (I deteſt) an honeſt maid as euer
broke bread: wee had an howres talke of that wart; I
ſhall neuer laugh but in that maids company: but (in-
deed) ſhee is giuen too much to Allicholy and muſing:
but for you — well — goe too —

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: I ſhall ſee her to day: hold, there’s mo-
ney for thee: Let mee haue thy voice in my behalfe: if
thou ſeeſt her before me, commend me.—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Will I? I faith that wee will: And I will tell
your Worſhip more of the Wart, the next time we haue
confidence, and of other wooers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, fare-well, I am in great haſte now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Fare-well to your Worſhip: truely an honeſt
Gentleman: but Anne loues him not: for I know Ans
minde as well as another do’s: out vpon’t: what haue I
forgot.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Miſtris Page, Miſtris Ford, Maſter Page, Maſter Ford, Piſtoll, Nim, Quickly, Hoſt, Shallow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: What, haue ſcap’d Loue-letters in the
holly-day-time of my beauty, and am I now a ſubieƈt
for them? let me ſee?

LINE.RECITE: Aske me no reaſon why I loue you, for though Loue vſe Rea-
ſon for his preciſian, hee admits him not for his Counſailour:
you are not yong, no more am I: goe to then, there’s ſimpathie:
you are merry, ſo am I: ha, ha, then there’s more ſimpathie:
you loue ſacke, and ſo do I: would you deſire better ſimpathie?
Let it ſuffice thee (Miſtris Page) at the leaſt if the Loue of
Souldier can ſuffice, that I loue thee: I will not ſay pitty mee,
‘tis not a Souldier-like phraſe; but I ſay, loue me:
By me, thine owne true Knight, by day or night:
Or any kinde of light, with all his might,

SPEECH.LINE: What a Herod of Iurie is this? O wicked, wicked world:
One that is well-nye worne to peeces with age
To ſhow himſelfe a yong Gallant? What an vnwaied
Behauiour hath this Flemiſh drunkard pickt (with
The Deuills name) out of my conuerſation, that he dares
In this manner aſſay me? why, hee hath not beene thrice
In my Company: what ſhould I ſay to him? I was then
Frugall of my mirth: (heauen forgiue mee:) why Ile
Exhibit a Bill in the Parliament for the putting downe
of men: how ſhall I be reueng’d on him? for reueng’d I
will be? as ſure as his guts are made of puddings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Miſtris Page, truſt me, I was going to your
houſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: And truſt me, I was comming to you: you
looke very ill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay Ile nere beleeee that; I haue to ſhew
to the contrary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Faith but you doe in my minde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: I doe then: yet I ſay, I could ſhew
you to the contrary: O Miſtris Page, giue mee ſome
counſaile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: What’s the matter, woman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: O woman: if it were not for one trifling re-
ſpeƈt, I could come to ſuch honour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang the trifle (woman) take the honour:
what is it? diſpence with trifles: what is it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: If I would but goe to hell, for an eternall
moment, or ſo: I could be knighted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: What thou lieſt? Sir Alice Ford? theſe
Knights will hacke, and ſo thou ſhouldſt not alter the ar-
ticle of thy Gentry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee burne day-light: heere, read, read:
perceiue how I might bee knighted, I ſhall thinke the
worſe of fat men, as long as I haue an eye to make diffe-
rence of mens liking: and yet hee would not ſweare:
praiſe womens modeſty: and gaue ſuch orderly and wel-
behaued reproofe to al vncomelineſſe, that I would haue
ſworne his diſpoſition would haue gone to the truth of
his words: but they doe no more adhere and keep place
together, then the hundred Pſalms to the tune of Green-
ſleeues: What tempeſt (I troa) threw this Whale, (with
ſo many Tuns of oyle in his belly) a’ſhoare at Windſor?
How ſhall I bee reuenged on him? I thinke the beſt way
were, to entertaine him with hope, till the wicked fire
of luſt haue melted him in his owne greace: Did you e-
uer heare the like?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Letter for letter; but that the name of
Page and Ford differs: to thy great comfort in this my-
ſtery of ill opinions, heere’s the twyn-brother of thy Let-
ter: but let thine inherit firſt, for I proteſt mine neuer
ſhall: I warrant he hath a thouſand of theſe Letters, writ
with blancke-ſpace for different names (ſure more): and
theſe are of the ſecond edition: hee will print them out
of doubt: for he cares not what hee puts into the preſſe,
when he would put vs two: I had rather be a Gianteſſe,
and lye vnder Mount Pelion: Well; I will find you twen-
tie laſciuious Turtles ere one chaſte man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Why this is the very ſame: the very hand:
the very words: what doth he thinke of vs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay I know not: it makes me almoſt rea-
die to wrangle with mine owne honeſty: Ile entertaine
my ſelfe like one that I am not acquainted withall: for
ſure vnleſſe hee know ſome ſtraine in mee, that I know
not my ſelfe, hee would neuer haue boorded me in this
furie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Boording, call you it? Ile bee ſure to keepe
him aboue decke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: So will I: if hee come vnder my hatches,
Ile neuer to Sea againe: Let’s bee reueng’d on him: let’s
appoint him a meeting: giue him a ſhow of comfort in
his Suit, and lead him on with a fine baited delay, till hee
hath pawn’d his horſes to mine Hoſt of the Garter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I wil conſent to aƈt any villany againſt
him, that may not ſully the charineſſe of our honeſty: oh
that my husband ſaw this Letter: it would giue eternall
food to his iealouſie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Why look where he comes; and my good
man too: hee’s as farre from iealouſie, as I am from gi-
uing him cauſe, and that (I hope) is an vnmeaſurable di-
ſtance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: You are the happier woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Let’s conſult together againſt this greaſie
Knight: Come hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: I hope, it be not ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Hope is a curtall-dog in ſome affaires:
Sir Iohn affeƈts thy wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſir, my wife is not young.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: He wooes both high and low, both rich & poor,
both yong and old, one with another (Ford) he loues the
Gally-mawfry (Ford) perpend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Loue my wife?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: With liuer, burning hot: preuent:
Or goe thou like Sir Aƈteon he, with
Ring-wood at thy heeles: O, odious is the name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What name Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: The horne I ſay: Farewell:
Take heed, haue open eye, for theeues doe foot by night.
Take heed, ere ſommer comes, or Cuckoo-birds do ſing.
Away ſir Corporall Nim:
Beleeue it (Page) he ſpeakes ſence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I will be patient: I will find out this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nim.
SPEECH.LINE: And this is true: I like not the humor of lying:
hee hath wronged mee in ſome humors: I ſhould haue
borne the humour’d Letter to her: but I haue a ſword:
and it ſhall bite vpon my neceſſitie: he loues your wife;
There’s the ſhort and the long: My name is Corporall
Nim: I ſpeak, and I auouch; ‘tis true: my name is Nim:
and Falſtaffe loues your wife: adieu, I loue not the hu-
mour of bread and cheeſe: adieu.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: The humour of it (quoth’a?) heere’s a fellow
frights Engliſh out of his wits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I will ſeeke out Falſtaffe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I neuer heard ſuch a drawling-affeƈting rogue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: If I doe finde it: well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I will not beleeue ſuch a Cataian, though the
Prieſt o’ th’ Towne commended him for a true man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Twas a good ſenſible fellow: well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Meg?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Whether goe you (George?) harke you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: How now (ſweet Frank) why art thou me-
lancholy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I melancholy? I am not melancholy:
Get you home: goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith, thou haſt ſome crochets in thy head,
Now: will you goe, Miſtris Page?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue with you: you’ll come to dinner
George? Looke who comes yonder: ſhee ſhall bee our
Meſſenger to this paltrie Knight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Truſt me, I thought on her: ſhee’ll fit it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: You are come to ſee my daughter Anne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: I forſooth: and I pray how do’s good Miſtreſſe

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Go in with vs and ſee: we haue an houres
talke with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Maſter Ford?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: For.
SPEECH.LINE: You heard what this knaue told me, did you not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, and you heard what the other told me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe you thinke there is truth in them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang ‘em ſlaues: I doe not thinke the Knight
would offer it: But theſe that accuſe him in his intent
towards our wiues, are a yoake of his diſcarded men: ve-
ry rogues, now they be out of ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Were they his men?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry were they.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I like it neuer the beter for that,
Do’s he lye at the Garter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I marry do’s he: if hee ſhould intend this voy-
age toward my wife, I would turne her looſe to him;
and what hee gets more of her, then ſharpe words, let it
lye on my head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe not miſdoubt my wife: but I would bee
loath to turne them together: a man may be too confi-
dent: I would haue nothing lye on my head: I cannot
be thus ſatisfied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke where my ranting-Hoſt of the Garter
comes: there is eyther liquor in his pate, or mony in his
purſe, when hee lookes ſo merrily: How now mine
Hoſt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Bully-Rooke: thou’rt a Gentleman
Caueleiro Iuſtice, I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: I follow, (mine Hoſt) I follow: Good-euen,
and twenty (good Maſter Page.) Maſter Page, wil you go
with vs? we haue ſport in hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell him Caueleiro-Iuſtice: tell him Bully-
Rooke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shall.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, there is a fray to be fought, betweene Sir
Hugh the Welch Prieſt, and Caius the French Doƈtor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Good mine Hoſt o’th’ Garter: a word with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſaiſt thou, my Bully-Rooke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you goe with vs to behold it? My merry
Hoſt hath had the meaſuring of their weapons; and (I
thinke) hath appointed them contrary places: for (be-
leeue mee) I heare the Parſon is no Ieſter: harke, I will
tell you what our ſport ſhall be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Haſt thou no ſuit againſt my Knight? my gueſt-
Caualeire?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: None, I proteſt: but Ile giue you a pottle of
burn’d ſacke, to giue me recourſe to him, and tell him
my name is Broome: onely for a ieſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: My hand, (Bully:) thou ſhalt haue egreſſe and
regreſſe, (ſaid I well?) and thy name ſhall be Broome. It
is a merry Knight: will you goe An-heires?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue with you mine Hoſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue heard the French-man hath good skill
in his Rapier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Tut ſir: I could haue told you more: In theſe
times you ſtand on diſtance: your Paſſes, Stoccado’s, and
I know not what: ‘tis the heart (Maſter Page) ‘tis heere,
‘tis heere: I haue ſeene the time, with my long-ſword, I
would haue made you fowre tall fellowes ſkippe like
Rattes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere boyes, heere, heere: ſhall we wag?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue with you: I had rather heare them ſcold,
then fight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Though Page be a ſecure foole, and ſtands ſo
firmely on his wiues frailty; yet, I cannot put-off my o-
pinion ſo eaſily: ſhe was in his company at Pages houſe:
and what they made there, I know not. Well, I wil looke
further into’t, and I haue a diſguiſe, to ſound Falſtaffe; if
I finde her honeſt, I looſe not my labor: if ſhe be other-
wiſe, ‘tis labour well beſtowed.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Falſtaffe, Piſtoll, Robin, Quickly, Bardolffe, Ford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I will not lend thee a penny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then the world’s mine Oyſter, which I,
with ſword will open.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Not a penny: I haue beene content (Sir,) you
ſhould lay my countenance to pawne: I haue grated vp-
on my good friends for three Repreeues for you, and
your Coach-fellow Nim; or elſe you had look’d through
the grate, like a Geminy of Baboones: I am damn’d in
hell, for ſwearing to Gentlemen my friends, you were
good Souldiers, and tall-fellowes. And when Miſtreſſe
Briget loſt the handle of her Fan, I took’t vpon mine ho-
nour thou hadſt it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Didſt not thou ſhare? hadſt thou not fifteene
pence?

SCENE.SPEECH: Fal. Reaſon, you roague, reaſon: thinkſt thou Ile en- danger my ſoule, gratis? at a word, hang no more about mee, I am no gibbet for you: goe, a ſhort knife, and a throng, to your Mannor of Pickt-hatch: goe, you’ll not beare a Letter for mee you roague? you ſtand vpon your honor: why, (thou vnconfinable baſeneſſe) it is as much as I can doe to keepe the termes of my hononor preciſe: I, I, I my ſelfe ſometimes, leauing the feare of heauen on the left hand, and hiding mine honor in my neceſſity, am faine to ſhufflle: to hedge, and to lurch, and yet, you Rogue, will en-ſconce your raggs; your Cat-a-Moun- taine-lookes, your red-lattice phraſes, and your bold- beating-oathes, vnder the ſhelter of your honor? you will not doe it? you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe relent: what would thou more of man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robin.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, here’s a woman would ſpeake with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Let her approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue your worſhip good morrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Good-morrow, good-wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo, and’t pleaſe your worſhip.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Good maid then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile be ſworne,
As my mother was the firſt houre I was borne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe beleeue the ſwearer; what with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I vouch-ſafe your worſhip a word, or
two?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Two thouſand (faire woman) and ile vouchſafe
thee the hearing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: There is one Miſtreſſe Ford, (Sir) I pray come a
little neerer this waies: I my ſelfe dwell with M.Doƈtor

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, on; Miſtreſſe Ford, you ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Your worſhip ſaies very true: I pray your wor-
ſhip come a little neerer this waies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I warrant thee, no-bodie heares: mine owne
people, mine owne people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Are they ſo? heauen-bleſſe them, and make
them his Seruants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Well; Miſtreſſe Ford, what of her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, Sir; ſhee’s a good-creature; Lord, Lord,
your Worſhip’s a wanton: well: heauen forgiue you,
and all of vs, I pray——.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Miſtreſſe Ford: come, Miſtreſſe Ford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry this is the ſhort, and the long of it: you
haue brought her into ſuch a Canaries, as ‘tis wonder-
full: the beſt Courtier of them all (when the Court lay
at Windſor) could neuer haue brought her to ſuch a Ca-
narie: yet there has beene Knights, and Lords, and Gen-
tlemen, with their Coaches; I warrant you Coach after
Coach, letter after letter, gift after gift, ſmelling ſo ſweet-
ly; all Muske, and ſo ruſhling, I warrant you, in ſilke
and golde, and in ſuch alligant termes, and in ſuch wine
and ſuger of the beſt, and the faireſt, that would haue
wonne any womans heart: and I warrant you, they could
neuer get an eye-winke of her: I had my ſelfe twentie
Angels giuen me this morning, but I defie all Angels (in
any ſuch ſort, as they ſay) but in the way of honeſty: and
I warrant you, they could neuer get her ſo much as ſippe
on a cup with the prowdeſt of them all, and yet there has
beene Earles: nay, (which is more) Pentioners, but I
warrant you all is one with her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: But what ſaies ſhee to mee? be briefe my good
ſhee-Mercurie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, ſhe hath receiu’d your Letter: for the
which ſhe thankes you a thouſand times; and ſhe giues
you to notifie, that her husband will be abſence from his
houſe, betweene ten and eleuen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Ten, and eleuen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: I, forſooth: and then you may come and ſee the
piƈture (she ſayes) that you wot of: Maƈtter Ford her huſ-
band will be from home: alas, the ſweet woman leades
an ill life with him: hee’s a very iealouſie-man; ſhe leads
a very frampold life with him, (good hart.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Ten, and eleuen.
Woman, commend me to her, I will not faile her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, you ſay well: But I haue another meſſen-
ger to your worſhip: Miſtreſſe Page hath her heartie
commendations to you to: and let mee tell you in your
eare, ſhee’s as fartuous a ciuill modeſt wife, and one (I
tell you) that will not miſſe you morning nor euening
prayer, as any is in Windſor, who ere bee the other: and
ſhee bade me tell your worſhip, that her husband is ſel-
dome from home, but ſhe hopes there will come a time.
I neuer knew a woman ſo doate vpon a man; ſurely I
thinke you haue charmes, la: yes in truth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Not I, I aſſure thee; ſetting the attraſion of my
good parts aſide, I haue no other charmes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Bleſſing on your heart for’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: But I pray thee tell me this: has Fords wife, and
Pages wife acquainted each other, how they loue me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: That were a ieſt indeed: they haue not ſo little
grace I hope, that were a tricke indeed: But Miſtris Page
would deſire you to ſend her your little Page of al loues:
her husband has a maruellous infeƈtió to the little Page:
and truely Maſter Page is an honeſt man: neuer a wife in
Windſor leades a better life then ſhe do’s: doe what ſhee
will, ſay what ſhe will, take all, pay all, goe to bed when
ſhe list, riſe when ſhe list, all is as ſhe will: and truly ſhe
deſerues it; for if there be a kinde woman in Windſor, ſhe
is one: you muſt ſend her your Page, no remedie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, I will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but doe ſo then, and looke you, hee may
come and goe betweene you both: and in any caſe haue
a nay-word, that you may know one anothers minde,
and the Boy neuer neede to vnderſtand any thing; for
‘tis not good that children ſhould know any wickednes:
olde folkes you know, haue diſcretion, as they ſay, and
know the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Farethee-well, commend mee to them both:
there’s my purſe, I am yet thy debter: Boy, goe along
with this woman, this newes diſtraƈts me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: This Puncke is one of Cupids Carriers,
Clap on more ſailes, purſue: vp with your ſights:
Giue fire: ſhe is my prize, or Ocean whelme them all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Saiſt thou ſo (old Iacke) go thy waies: Ile make
more of thy olde body then I haue done: will they yet
looke after thee? wilt thou after the expence of ſo much
money, be now a gainer? good Body, I thanke thee: let
them ſay ‘tis groſſely done, ſo it bee fairely done, no
matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Iohn, there’s one Maſter Broome below would
faine ſpeake with you, and be acquainted with you; and
hath ſent your worſhip a mornings draught of Sacke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Broome is his name?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: I Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Call him in: ſuch Broomes are welcome to mee,
that ore’flowes ſuch liquor: ah ha, Miſtreſſe Ford and Mi-
ſtreſſe Page, haue I encompaſs’d you? goe to, via.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Bleſſe you ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: And you ſir: would you ſpeake with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I make bold, to preſſe, with ſo little prepara-
tion vpon you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: You’r welcome, what’s your will? giue vs leaue
Drawer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I am a Gentleman that haue ſpent much,
my name is Broome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Maſter Broome, I deſire more acquaintance
of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Sir Iohn, I ſue for yours: not to charge
you, for I muſt let you vnderſtand, I thinke my ſelfe in
better plight for a Lender, then you are: the which hath
ſomething emboldned me to this vnſeaſon’d intruſion:
for they ſay, if money goe before, all waies doe lye
open.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Money is a good Souldier (Sir) and will on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Troth, and I haue a bag of money heere trou-
bles me: if you will helpe to beare it (Sir Iohn) take all,
or halfe, for eaſing me of the carriage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I know not how I may deſerue to bee your
Porter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I will tell you ſir, if you will giue mee the hea-
ring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake (good Maſter Broome) I ſhall be glad to
be your Seruant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I heare you are a Scholler: (I will be briefe
with you) and you haue been a man long knowne to me,
though I had neuer ſo good means as deſire, to make my
ſelfe acquainted with you. I ſhall diſcouer a thing to
you, wherein I muſt very much lay open mine owne im-
perfeƈtion: but (good Sir Iohn) as you haue one eye vp-
on my follies, as you heare them vnfolded, turne another
into the Regiſter of your owne, that I may paſſe with a
reproofe the eaſier, ſith you your ſelfe know how eaſie it
is to be ſuch an offender.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Very well Sir, proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: There is a Gentlewoman in this Towne, her
husbands name is Ford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Well Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue long lou’d her, and I proteſt to you, be-
ſtowed much on her: followed her with a doating ob-
ſeruance: Ingroſs’d opportunities to meete her: fee’d e-
uery ſlight occaſion that could but nigardly giue mee
ſight of her: not only bought many preſents to giue her,
but haue giuen largely to many, to know what ſhee
would haue giuen: briefly, I haue purſu’d her, as Loue
hath purſued mee, which hath beene on the wing of all
occaſions: but whatſoeuer I haue merited, either in my
minde, or in my meanes, meede I am ſure I haue receiued
none, vnleſſe Experience be a Iewell, that I haue purcha-
ſed at an infinite rate, and that hath taught mee to ſay
this,
"Loue like a ſhadow flies, when ſubſtance Loue purſues,
"Purſuing that that flies, and flying what purſues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue you receiu’d no promiſe of ſatiſfaƈtion at
her hands?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Neuer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue you importun’d her to ſuch a purpoſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Neuer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Of what qualitie was your loue then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Like a fair houſe, built on another mans ground,
ſo that I haue loſt my edifice, by miſtaking the place,
where I ereƈted it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: To what purpoſe haue you vnfolded this to me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: For.
SPEECH.LINE: When I haue told you that, I haue told you all:
Some ſay, that though ſhe appeare honeſt to mee, yet in
other places ſhee enlargeth her mirth ſo farre, that there
is ſhrewd conſtruƈtion made of her. Now (Sir Iohn) here
is the heart of my purpoſe: you are a gentleman of ex-
cellent breeding, admirable diſcourſe, of great admit-
tance, authenticke in your place and perſon, generally
allow’d for your many war-like, court-like, and learned
preparations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: O Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Beleeue it, for you know it: there is money,
ſpend it, ſpend it, ſpend more; ſpend all I haue, onely
giue me ſo much of your time in enchange of it, as to lay
an amiable ſiege to the honeſty of this Fords wife: vſe
your Art of wooing; win her to conſent to you: if any
man may, you may as ſoone as any.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Would it apply well to the vehemency of your
affeƈtion that I ſhould win what you would enioy? Me-
thinkes you preſcribe to your ſelfe very prepoſterously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: O, vnderſtand my drift: ſhe dwells ſo ſecurely
on the excellency of her honor, that the folly of my ſoule
dares not preſent it ſelfe: ſhee is too bright to be look’d
againſt. Now, could I come to her with any deteƈtion
in my hand; my deſires had inſtance and argument to
commend themſelues, I could driue her then from the
ward of her purity, her reputation, her marriage-vow,
and a thouſand other her defences, which now are too-
too ſtrongly embattaild againſt me: what ſay you too’t,
Sir Iohn?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Maſter Broome, I will firſt make bold with your
money: next, giue mee your hand: and laſt, as I am a
gentleman, you ſhall, if you will, enioy Fords wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: O good Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay you ſhall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Want no money (Sir Iohn) you ſhall want none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Want no Miſtreſſe Ford (Maſter Broome) you ſhall
want none: I ſhall be with her (I may tell you) by her
owne appointment, euen as you came in to me, her aſſi-
ſtant, or goe-betweene, parted from me: I ſay I ſhall be
with her betweene ten and eleuen: for at that time the
iealious-raſcally-knaue her husband will be forth: come
you to me at night, you ſhall know how I ſpeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I am bleſt in your acquaintance: do you know
Ford Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang him (poore Cuckoldly knaue) I know
him not: yet I wrong him to call him poore: They ſay
the iealous wittolly-knaue hath maſſes of money, for
the which his wife ſeemes to me well-fauourd: I will vſe
her as the key of the Cuckoldly-rogues Coffer, & ther’s
my harueſt-home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I would you knew Ford, ſir, that you might a-
uoid him, if you ſaw him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang him, mechanicall-ſalt-butter rogue; I wil
ſtare him out of his wits: I will awe-him with my cud-
gell: it ſhall hang like a Meteor ore the Cuckolds horns:
Maſter Broome, thou ſhalt know, I will predominate o-
uer the pezant, and thou ſhalt lye with his wife. Come
to me ſoone at night: Ford’s a knaue, and I will aggra-
uate his ſtile: thou (Maſter Broome) ſhalt know him for
knaue, and Cuckold. Come to me ſoone at night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What a damn’d Epicurian-Raſcall is this? my
heart is ready to cracke with impatience: who ſaies this
is improuident iealouſie? my wife hath ſent to him, the
howre is fixt, the match is made: would any man haue
thought this? ſee the hell of hauing a falſe woman: my
bed ſhall be abus’d, my Coffers ranſack’d, my reputati-
on gnawne at, and I ſhall not onely receiue this villanous
wrong, but ſtand vnder the adoption of abhominable
termes, and by him that does mee this wrong: Termes,
names: Amaimon ſounds well: Lucifer, well: Barbaſon,
well: yet they are Diuels additions, the names of fiends:
But Cuckold, Wittoll, Cuckold? the Diuell himſelfe
hath not ſuch a name. Page is an Aſſe, a ſecure Aſſe; hee
will truſt his wife, hee will not be iealous: I will rather
truſt a Fleming with my butter, Parſon Hugh the Welſh-
man with my Cheeſe, an Iriſh-man with my Aqua-vitæ-
bottle, or a Theefe to walke my ambling gelding, then
my wife with her ſelfe. Then ſhe plots, then ſhee rumi-
nates, then ſhee deuiſes: and what they thinke in their
hearts they may effeƈt; they will breake their hearts but
they will effeƈt. Heauen bee prais’d for my iealouſie:
eleuen o’ clocke the howre, I will preuent this, deteƈt
my wife, bee reueng’d on Falſtaffe, and laugh at Page. I
will about it, better three houres too ſoone, then a my-
nute too late: fie, fie, fie: Cuckold, Cuckold, Cuckold.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Caius, Rugby, Page, Shallow, Slender, Hoſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rug.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caius.
SPEECH.LINE: Vat is the clocke, Iack.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rug.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis paſt the howre (Sir) that Sir Hugh promis’d
to meet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By gar, he has ſaue his ſoule, dat he is no-come:
hee has pray his Pible well, dat he is no-come: by gar
(Iack Rugby) he is dead already, if he be come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rug.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee is wiſe Sir: hee knew your worſhip would
kill him if he came.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By gar, de herring is no dead, ſo as I vill kill
him: take your Rapier, (Iacke) I vill tell you how I vill
kill him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rug.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas ſir, I cannot fence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Villaine, take your Rapier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rug.
SPEECH.LINE: Forbeare: heer’s company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Bleſſe thee, bully-Doƈtor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Saue you Mr. Doƈtor Caius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Now good Mr. Doƈtor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Giue you good-morrow, ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caius.
SPEECH.LINE: Vat be all you one, two, tree, fowre, come for?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: To ſee thee fight, to ſee thee foigne, to ſee thee
trauerſe, to ſee thee heere, to ſee thee there, to ſee thee
paſſe thy punƈto, thy ſtock, thy reuerſe, thy diſtance, thy
montant: Is he dead, my Ethiopian? Is he dead, my Fran-
ciſco? ha Bully? what ſaies my Eſculapius? my Galien?
my heart of Elder? ha? is he dead bully-Stale? is he dead?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By gar, he is de Coward-Iack-Prieſt of de vorld:
he is not ſhow his face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art a Caſtalion-king-Vrinall: Heƈtor of
Greece (my Boy)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you beare witneſſe, that me haue ſtay,
ſixe or ſeuen, two tree howres for him, and hee is no-
come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: He is the wiſer man (M. Doƈtor) he is a curer of
ſoules, and you a curer of bodies: if you ſhould fight, you
goe againſt the haire of your profeſſions: is it not true,
Maſter Page?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Maſter Shallow; you haue your ſelfe beene a
great fighter, though now a man of peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Body-kins M. Page, though I now be old, and
of the peace; if I ſee a ſword out, my finger itches to
make one: though wee are Iuſtices, and Doƈtors, and
Church-men (M. Page) wee haue ſome ſalt of our youth
in vs, we are the ſons of women (M. Page.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis true, Mr. Shallow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: It wil be found ſo, (M. Page:) M. Doƈtor Caius,
I am come to fetch you home: I am ſworn of the peace:
you haue ſhow’d your ſelfe a wiſe Phyſician, and Sir
Hugh hath ſhowne himſelfe a wiſe and patient Church-
man: you muſt goe with me, M. Doƈtor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon, Gueſt-Iuſtice; a Mounſeur Mocke-
water.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Mock-vater? vat is dat?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Mock-water, in our Engliſh tongue, is Valour
(Bully.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By gar, then I haue as much Mock-vater as
de Engliſhman: ſcuruy-Iack-dog-Prieſt: by gar, mee vill
cut his eares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: He will Clapper-claw thee tightly (Bully.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Clapper-de-claw? vat is dat?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: That is, he will make thee amends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By-gar, me doe looke hee ſhall clapper-de-claw
me, for by-gar, me vill haue it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: And I will prouoke him to’t, or let him wag.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Me tanck you for dat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: And moreouer, (Bully) but firſt, Mr. Ghueſt,
and M. Page, & eeke Caualeiro Slender, goe you through
the Towne to Frogmore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Hugh is there, is he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: He is there, ſee what humor he is in: and I will
bring the Doƈtor about by the Fields: will it doe well?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: We will doe it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Adieu, good M. Doƈtor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By-gar, me vill kill de Prieſt, for he ſpeake for a
Iack-an-Ape to Anne Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Let him die: ſheath thy impatience: throw cold
water on thy Choller: goe about the fields with mee
through Frogmore, I will bring thee where Miſtris Anne
Page is, at a Farm-houſe a Feaſting: and thou ſhalt wooe
her: Cride-game, ſaid I well?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By-gar, mee dancke you vor dat: by gar I loue
you: and I ſhall procure ‘a you de good Gueſt: de Earle,
de Knight, de Lords, de Gentlemen, my patients.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: For the which, I will be thy aduerſary toward
Anne Page: ſaid I well?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By-gar, ‘tis good: vell ſaid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Let vs wag then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Come at my heeles, Iack Rugby.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Euans, Simple, Page, Shallow, Slender, Hoſt, Caius, Rugby.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you now, good Maſter Slenders ſeruing-
man, and friend Simple by your name; which way haue
you look’d for Maſter Caius, that calls himſelfe Doƈtor
of Phiſicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry Sir, the pittie-ward, the Parke-ward:
euery way: olde Windſor way, and euery way but the
Towne-way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: I moſt fehemently deſire you, you will alſo
looke that way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim.
SPEECH.LINE: I will ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Pleſſe my ſoule: how full of Chollors I am, and
trempling of minde: I ſhall be glad if he haue deceiued
me: how melancholies I am? I will knog his Vrinalls a-
bout his knaues coſtard, when I haue good oportunities
for the orke: ‘Pleſſe my ſoule: To ſhallow Riuers to whoſe

LINE.ITALIC: falls: melodious Birds ſings Madrigalls: There will we make
our Peds of Roſes: and a thouſand fragrant poſies. To ſhal-

SPEECH.LINE: low: ‘Mercie on mee, I haue a great diſpoſitions to cry.

LINE.ITALIC: Melodious birds ſing Madrigalls: — When as I ſat in Pa-
bilon: and a thouſand vagram Poſies. To ſhallow, &c.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim.
SPEECH.LINE: Yonder he is comming, this way, Sir Hugh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee’s welcome: To ſhallow Riuers, to whoſe fals:
Heauen proſper the right: what weapons is he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim.
SPEECH.LINE: No weapons, Sir: there comes my Maſter, Mr.
Shallow, and another Gentleman; from Frogmore, ouer
the ſtile, this way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you giue mee my gowne, or elſe keepe it
in your armes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Maſter Parſon? good morrow good
Sir Hugh: keepe a Gameſter from the dice, and a good
Studient from his booke, and it is wonderfull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Ah ſweet Anne Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Saue you, good Sir Hugh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Pleſſe you from his mercy-ſake, all of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: What? the Sword, and the Word?
Doe you ſtudy them both, Mr. Parſon?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: And youthfull ſtill, in your doublet and hoſe,
this raw-rumaticke day?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: There is reaſons, and cauſes for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: We are come to you, to doe a good office, Mr.
Parſon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Fery-well: what is it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Yonder is a moſt reuerend Gentleman; who
(be-like) hauing receiued wrong by ſome perſon, is at
moſt odds with his owne grauity and patience, that euer
you ſaw.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue liued foure-ſcore yeeres, and vpward: I
neuer heard a man of his place, grauity, and learning, ſo
wide of his owne respeƈt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: What is he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke you know him: Mr. Doƈtor Caius the
renowned French Phyſician.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Got’s-will, and his paſſion of my heart: I had
as lief you would tell me of a meſſe of porredge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: He has no more knowledge in Hibocrates and
Galen and hee is a knaue beſides: a cowardly knaue, as
you would deſires to be acquainted withall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I warrant you, hee’s the man ſhould fight with
him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſweet Anne Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: It appeares ſo by his weapons: keepe them a-
ſunder: here comes Doƈtor Caius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay good Mr. Parſon, keepe in your weapon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: So doe you, good Mr. Doƈtor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Diſarme them, and let them queſtion: let them
keepe their limbs whole, and hack our Engliſh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you let-a-mee ſpeake a word with your
eare; vherefore vill you not meet-a me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you vſe your patience in good time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By-gar, you are de Coward: de Iack dog: Iohn
Ape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you let vs not be laughing-ſtocks to other
mens humors: I deſire you in friendſhip, and I will one
way or other make you amends: I will knog your Vrinal
about your knaues Cogs-combe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Diable: Iack Rugby: mine Hoſt de Iarteer: haue I
not ſtay for him, to kill him? haue I not at de place I did
appoint?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: As I am a Chriſtians-soule, now looke you:
this is the place appointed, Ile bee iudgement by mine

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, I ſay, Gallia and Gaule, French & Welch,
Soule-Curer, and Body-Curer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: I, dat is very good, excellant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, I ſay: heare mine Hoſt of the Garter,
Am I politicke? Am I ſubtle? Am I a Machiuell?
Shall I looſe my Doƈtor? No, hee giues me the Potions
and the Motions. Shall I looſe my Parſon? my Prieſt?
my Sir Hugh? No, he giues me the Prouerbes, and the
No-verbes. Giue me thy hand (Celeſtiall) ſo: Boyes of
Art, I haue deceiu’d you both: I haue direƈted you to
wrong places: your hearts are mighty, your ſkinnes are
whole, and let burn’d Sacke be the iſſue: Come, lay their
ſwords to pawne: Follow me, Lad of peace, follow, fol-
low, follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Truſt me, a mad Hoſt: follow Gentlemen, fol-
low.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſweet Anne Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha’ do I perceiue dat? Haue you make-a-de-ſot of
vs, ha, ha?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: This is well, he has made vs his vlowting-ſtog:
I deſire you that we may be friends: and let vs knog our
praines together to be reuenge on this ſame ſcall ſcur-
uy-cogging-companion the Hoſt of the Garter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By gar, with all my heart: he promiſe to bring
me where is Anne Page: by gar he deceiue me too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I will ſmite his noddles: pray you follow.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Miſt. Page, Robin, Ford, Page, Shallow, Slender, Hoſt, Euans, Caius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay keepe your way (little Gallant) you
were wont to be a follower, but now you are a Leader:
whether had you rather lead mine eyes, or eye your ma-
ſters heeles?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rob.
SPEECH.LINE: I had rather (forſooth) go before you like a man,
then follow him like a dwarfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: O you are a flattering boy, now I ſee you’l be a Courtier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Well met miſtris Page, whether go you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: Truly Sir, to ſee your wife, is ſhe at home?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and as idle as ſhe may hang together for want
of company: I thinke if your husbands were dead, you
two would marry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: Be ſure of that, two other husbands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Where had you this pretty weather-cocke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot tell what (the dickens) his name is my
husband had him of, what do you cal your Knights name ſirrah?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rob.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Iohn Falſtaffe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Iohn Falſtaffe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: He, he, I can neuer hit on’s name; there is ſuch a
league betweene my goodman, and he: is your Wife at home indeed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed ſhe is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: By your leaue ſir, I am ſicke till I ſee her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Has Page any braines? Hath he any eies? Hath he
any thinking? Sure they ſleepe, he hath no vſe of them:
why this boy will carrie a letter twentie mile as eaſie, as
a Canon will ſhoot point-blanke twelue ſcore: hee pee-
ces out his wiues inclination: he giues her folly motion
and aduantage: and now ſhe’s going to my wife, & Fal-
ſtaffes boy with her: A man may heare this ſhowre ſing
in the winde; and Falſtaffes boy with her: good plots,
they are laide, and our reuolted wiues ſhare damnation
together. Well, I will take him, then torture my wife,
plucke the borrowed vaile of modeſtie from the ſo-ſee-
ming Miſt. Page, divulge Page himſelfe for a ſecure and
wilfull Aƈteon, and to theſe violent proceedings all my
neighbors ſhall cry aime. The clocke giues me my Qu,
and my aſſurance bids me ſearch, there I ſhall finde Fal-
ſtaffe: I ſhall be rather praiſd for this, then mock’d, for
it is as poſſitiue, as the earth is firme, that Falſtaffe is
there: I will go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal. Page, &c.
SPEECH.LINE: Well met Mr Ford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Truſt me, a good knotte; I haue good cheere at
home, and I pray you all go with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: I muſt excuſe my ſelfe Mr Ford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo muſt I Sir,
We haue appointed to dine with Miſtris Anne,
And I would not breake with her for more mony
Then Ile ſpeake of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: We haue linger’d about a match betweene An
Page, and my cozen Slender, and this day wee ſhall haue
our anſwer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I hope I haue your good will Father Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue Mr Slender, I ſtand wholly for you,
But my wife (Mr Doƈtor) is for you altogether.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: I be-gar, and de Maid is loue-a-me: my nurſh-
a-Quickly tell me ſo muſh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſay you to yong Mr Fenton? He capers,
he dances, he has eies of youth: he writes verſes, hee
ſpeakes holliday, he ſmels April and May, he wil carry’t,
he will carry’t, ‘tis in his buttons, he will carry’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Not by my conſent I promiſe you. The Gentle-
man is of no hauing, hee kept companie with the wilde
Prince, and Pointz: he is of too high a Region, he knows
too much: no, hee ſhall not knit a knot in his fortunes,
with the finger of my ſubſtance: if he take her, let him
take her ſimply: the wealth I haue waits on my conſent,
and my conſent goes not that way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I beſeech you heartily, ſome of you goe home
with me to dinner: beſides your cheere you ſhall haue
ſport, I will ſhew you a monſter: Mr Doƈtor, you ſhal
go, ſo ſhall you Mr Page, and you Sir Hugh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, fare you well:
We ſhall haue the freer woing at Mr Pages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Go home Iohn Rugby, I come anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell my hearts, I will to my honeſt Knight
Falſtaffe, and drinke Canarie with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke I ſhall drinke in Pipe-wine firſt with
him, Ile make him dance. Will you go Gentles?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue with you, to ſee this Monſter.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter M. Ford, M. Page, Seruants, Robin, Falſtaffe, Ford, Page, Caius, Euans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What Iohn, what Robert.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Quickly, quickly: Is the Buck-basket—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I warrant. What Robin I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere, ſet it downe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue your men the charge, we muſt be briefe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie, as I told you before (Iohn & Robert)
be ready here hard-by in the Brew-houſe, & when I ſo-
dainly call you, come forth, and (without any pauſe, or
ſtaggering) take this basket on your ſhoulders: ý done,
trudge with it in all haſt, and carry it among the Whit-
ſters in Dotchet Mead, and there empty it in the muddie
ditch, cloſe by the Thames ſide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: You will do it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I ha told them ouer and ouer, they lacke no direƈtion.
Be gone, and come when you are call’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Here comes little Robin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: How now my Eyas-Musket, what newes with you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rob.
SPEECH.LINE: My M.Sir Iohn is come in at your backe doore
(Miſt. Ford, and requeſts your company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: You litle Iack-a-lent, haue you bin true to vs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rob.
SPEECH.LINE: I, Ile be ſworne: my Maſter knowes not of your
being heere: and hath threatned to put me into euerla-
ſting liberty, if I tell you of it: for he ſweares he’ll turne
me away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou’rt a good boy: this ſecrecy of thine
ſhall be a Tailor to thee, and ſhal make thee a new dou-
blet and hoſe. Ile go hide me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Do ſo: go tell thy Maſter, I am alone: Mi-
ſtris Page, remember you your Qu.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: I warrant thee, if I do not aƈt it, hiſſe me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Go-too then: we’l vſe this vnwholſome
humidity, this groſſe-watry Pumpion; we’ll teach him
to know Turtles from Iayes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue I caught thee, my heauenly Iewell? Why
now let me die, for I haue liu’d long enough: This is the
period of my ambition: O this bleſſed houre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſweet Sir Iohn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Miſtris Ford, I cannot cog, I cannot prate (Miſt.
Ford) now ſhall I ſin in my wiſh; I would thy Husband
were dead, Ile ſpeake it before the beſt Lord, I would
make thee my Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I your Lady Sir Iohn? Alas, I ſhould bee a
pittifull Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Let the Court of France ſhew me ſuch another:
I ſee how thine eye would emulate the Diamond: Thou
haſt the right arched-beauty of the brow, that becomes
the Ship-tyre, the Tyre-valiant, or any Tire of Venetian
admittance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: A plaine Kerchiefe, Sir Iohn:
My browes become nothing elſe, nor that well neither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art a tyrant to ſay ſo: thou wouldſt make
an abſolute Courtier, and the firme fixture of thy foote,
would giue an excellent motion to thy gate, in a ſemi-
circled Farthingale. I ſee what thou wert if Fortune thy
foe, were not Nature thy friend: Come, thou canſt not
hide it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Beleeue me, ther’s no ſuch thing in me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: What made me loue thee? Let that perſwade
thee. Ther’s ſomething extraordinary in thee: Come, I
cannot cog, and ſay thou art this and that, like a-manie
of theſe liſping-hauthorne buds, that come like women
in mens apparrell, and ſmell like Bucklers-berry in ſim-
ple time: I cannot, but I loue thee, none but thee; and
thou deseru’ſt it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Do not betray me ſir, I fear you loue M. Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou mightſt as well ſay, I loue to walke by the
Counter-gate, which is as hatefull to me, as the reeke of
a Lime-kill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, heauen knowes how I loue you,
And you ſhall one day finde it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
