SPEECH.LINE: Keepe in that minde, Ile deſerue it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I muſt tell you, ſo you doe;
Or elſe I could not be in that minde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rob.
SPEECH.LINE: Miſtris Ford, Miſtris Ford: heere’s Miſtris Page at
the doore, ſweating, and blowing, and looking wildely,
and would needs ſpeake with you preſently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: She ſhall not ſee me, I will enſconce mee behinde
the Arras.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you do ſo, ſhe’s a very tatling woman.
Whats the matter? How now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: O miſtris Ford what haue you done?
You’r ſham’d, y’are ouerthrowne, y’are vndone for euer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What’s the matter, good miſtris Page?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: O weladay, miſt. Ford, hauing an honeſt man
to your husband, to giue him ſuch cauſe of ſuſpition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What cauſe of ſuſpition?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: What cauſe of ſuſpition? Out vpon you:
How am I miſtooke in you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Why (alas) what’s the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Your husband’s comming hether (Woman)
with all the Officers in Windſor, to ſearch for a Gentle-
man, that he ſayes is heere now in the houſe; by your
conſent to take an ill aduantage of his abſence: you are
vndone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis not ſo, I hope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray heauen it be not ſo, that you haue ſuch
a man heere: but ‘tis moſt certaine your husband’s com-
ming, with halfe Windſor at his heeles, to ſerch for ſuch
a one, I come before to tell you: If you know your ſelfe
cleere, why I am glad of it: but if you haue a friend here,
conuey, conuey him out. Be not amaz’d, call all your
ſenſes to you, defend your reputation, or bid farwell to
your good life for euer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhall I do? There is a Gentleman my
deere friend: and I feare not mine owne ſhame ſo much,
as his perill. I had rather then a thouſand pound he were
out of the houſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: For ſhame, neuer ſtand (you had rather, and
you had rather:) your husband’s heere at hand, bethinke
you of ſome conueyance: in the houſe you cannot hide
him. Oh, how haue you deceiu’d me? Looke, heere is a
basket, if he be of any reaſonable ſtature, he may creepe
in heere, and throw fowle linnen vpon him, as if it were
going to bucking: Or it is whiting time, ſend him by
your two men to Datchet-Meade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: He’s too big to go in there: what ſhall I do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me ſee’t, let me ſee’t, O let me ſee’t:
Ile in, Ile in: Follow your friends counſell, Ile in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: What Sir Iohn Falſtaffe? Are theſe your Let-
ters, Knight?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I loue thee, helpe mee away: let me creepe in
heere: ile neuer——

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Helpe to couer your maſter (Boy:) Call
your men (Miſt. Ford.) You diſſembling Knight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What Iohn, Robert, Iohn; Go, take vp theſe
cloathes heere, quickly: Wher’s the Cowle-ſtaffe? Look
how you drumble? Carry them to the Landreſſe in Dat-
chet mead: quickly, come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Pray you come nere: if I ſuſpeƈt without cauſe,
Why then make ſport at me, then let me be your ieſt,
I deſerue it: How now? Whether beare you this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: To the Landreſſe forſooth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, what haue you to doe whether they
beare it? You were beſt meddle with buck-waſhing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Buck? I would I could waſh my ſelfe of ý Buck:
Bucke, bucke, bucke, I bucke: I warrant you Bucke,
And of the ſeaſon too; it ſhall appeare.
Gentlemen, I haue dream’d to night, Ile tell you my
dreame: heere, heere, heere bee my keyes, aſcend my
Chambers, ſearch, ſeeke, finde out: Ile warrant wee’le
vnkennell the Fox. Let me ſtop this way firſt: ſo, now
vncape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Good maſter Ford, be contented:
You wrong your ſelfe too much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: True (maſter Page) vp Gentlemen,
You ſhall ſee ſport anon:
Follow me Gentlemen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: This is fery fantaſticall humors and iealouſies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caius.
SPEECH.LINE: By gar, ‘tis no-the faſhion of France:
It is not iealous in France.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay follow him (Gentlemen) ſee the yſſue of
his ſearch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Is there not a double excellency in this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I know not which pleaſes me better,
That my husband is deceiued, or Sir Iohn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: What a taking was hee in, when your
husband askt who was in the basket?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I am halfe affraid he will haue neede of
waſhing: ſo throwing him into the water, will doe him
a benefit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang him diſhonest raſcall: I would all
of the ſame ſtraine, were in the ſame diſtreſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke my husband hath ſome ſpeciall
ſuſpition of Falſtaffs being heere: for I neuer ſaw him ſo
groſſe in his iealouſie till now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I will lay a plot to try that, and wee will
yet haue more trickes with Falſtaffe: his diſſolute diſeaſe
will ſcarſe obey this medicine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall we ſend that fooliſhion Carion, Miſt.
Quickly to him, and excuſe his throwing into the water,
and giue him another hope, to betray him to another
puniſhment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: We will do it: let him be ſent for to mor-
row eight a clocke to haue amends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot finde him: may be the knaue bragg’d
of that he could not compaſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Heard you that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: You vſe me well, M. Ford? Do you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I, I do ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauen make you better then your thoghts

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: You do your ſelfe mighty wrong (M. Ford)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I, I: I muſt beare it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: If there be any pody in the houſe, & in the cham-
bers, and in the coffers, and in the preſſes: heauen for-
giue my ſins at the day of iudgement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Caius.
SPEECH.LINE: Be gar, nor I too: there is no-bodies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Fy, fy, M. Ford, are you not aſham’d? What ſpi-
rit, what diuell ſuggeſts this imagination? I wold not ha
your diſtemper in this kind, for ý welth of Windſor caſtle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis my fault (M. Page) I ſuffer for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſuffer for a pad conſcience: your wife is
as honeſt a o’mans, as I will deſires among fiue thou-
ſand, and fiue hundred too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: By gar, I ſee ‘tis an honeſt woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I promiſd you a dinner: come, come, walk
in the Parke, I pray you pardon me: I wil hereafter make
knowne to you why I haue done this. Come wife, come
Mi. Page, I pray you pardon me. Pray hartly pardon me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Let’s go in Gentlemen, but (truſt me) we’l mock
him: I doe inuite you to morrow morning to my houſe
to breakfaſt: after we’ll a Birding together, I haue a fine
Hawke for the buſh. Shall it be ſo:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Any thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: If there is one, I ſhall make two in the Companie

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ca.
SPEECH.LINE: If there be one, or two, I ſhall make-a-theturd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you go, M. Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you now remembrance to morrow on the
lowſie knaue, mine Hoſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Dat is good by gar, withall my heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: A lowſie knaue, to haue his gibes, and his moc-
keries.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Fenton, Anne, Page, Shallow, Slender, Quickly, Page, Miſt. Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſee I cannot get thy Fathers loue,
Therefore no more turne me to him (ſweet Nan.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anne.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, how then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Why thou muſt be thy ſelfe.
He doth obieƈt, I am too great of birth,
And that my ſtate being gall’d with my expence,
I ſeeke to heale it onely by his wealth.
Beſides theſe, other barres he layes before me,
My Riots paſt, my wilde Societies,
And tels me ‘tis a thing impoſſible
I ſhould loue thee, but as a property.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: May be he tels you true.
No, heauen ſo ſpeed me in my time to come,
Albeit I will confeſſe, thy Fathers wealth
Was the firſt motiue that I woo’d thee (Anne:)
Yet wooing thee, I found thee of more valew
Then ſtampes in Gold, or ſummes in ſealed bagges:
And ‘tis the very riches of thy ſelfe,
That now I ayme at.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: Gentle M. Fenton,
Yet ſeeke my Fathers loue, ſtill ſeeke it ſir,
If opportunity and humbleſt ſuite
Cannot attaine it, why then harke you hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Breake their talke Miſtris Quickly.
My Kinſman ſhall ſpeake for himſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile make a ſhaft or a bolt on’t, ſlid, tis but venturing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Be not diſmaid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: No, ſhe ſhall not diſmay me:
I care not for that, but that I am affeard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Hark ye, M. Slender would ſpeak a word with you

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: I come to him. This is my Fathers choice:
O what a world of vilde ill-fauour’d faults
Lookes handſome in three hundred pounds a yeere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: And how do’s good Maſter Fenton?
Pray you a word with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Shee’s comming; to her Coz:
O boy, thou hadſt a father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I had a father (M. An) my vncle can tel you good
ieſts of him: pray you Vncle, tel Miſt. Anne the ieſt how
my Father ſtole two Geeſe out of a Pen, good Vnckle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Miſtris Anne, my Cozen loues you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I that I do, as well as I loue any woman in Glo-
ceſterſhire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: He will maintaine you like a Gentlewoman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I that I will, come cut and long-taile, vnder the
degree of a Squire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: He will make you a hundred and fiftie pounds
ioynture.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anne.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Maiſter Shallow let him woo for him-
ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie I thanke you for it: I thanke you for
that good comfort: ſhe cals you (Coz) Ile leaue you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anne.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Maſter Slender.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Now good Miſtris Anne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anne.
SPEECH.LINE: What is your will?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: My will? Odd’s-hart-lings, that’s a prettie
ieſt indeede: I ne’re made my Will yet (I thanke Hea-
uen:) I am not ſuch a ſickely creature, I giue Heauen
praiſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anne.
SPEECH.LINE: I meane (M. Slender) what wold you with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Truely, for mine owne part, I would little or
nothing with you: your father and my vncle hath made
motions: if it be my lucke, ſo; if not, happy man bee his
dole, they can tell you how things go, better then I can:
you may aske your father, heere he comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Mr Slender; Loue him daughter Anne.
Why how now? What does Mr Fenten here?
You wrong me Sir, thus ſtill to haunt my houſe.
I told you Sir, my daughter is diſpoſd of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay Mr Page, be not impatient.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mist.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Good M. Fenton, come not to my child.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: She is no match for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, will you heare me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: No, good M. Fenton.
Come M. Shallow: Come ſonne Slender, in;
Knowing my minde, you wrong me (M. Fenton.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake to Miſtris Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Miſt. Page, for that I loue your daughter
In ſuch a righteous faſhion as I do,
Perforce, againſt all checkes, rebukes, and manners,
I muſt aduance the colours of my loue,
And not retire. Let me haue your good will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: Good mother, do not marry me to yond foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I meane it not, I ſeeke you a better huſ-
band.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s my maſter, M. Doƈtor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas I had rather be ſet quick i’th earth,
And bowl’d to death with Turnips.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, trouble not your ſelfe good M.
Fenton, I will not be your friend, nor enemy:
My daughter will I queſtion how ſhe loues you,
And as I finde her, ſo am I affeƈted:
Till then, farewell Sir, ſhe muſt needs go in,
Her father will be angry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell gentle Miſtris: farewell Nan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: This is my doing now: Nay, ſaide I, will you
caſt away your childe on a Foole, and a Phyſitian:
Looke on M. Fenton, this is my doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke thee: and I pray thee once to night,
Giue my ſweet Nan this Ring: there’s for thy paines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Now heauen ſend thee good fortune, a kinde
heart he hath: a woman would run through fire & wa-
ter for ſuch a kinde heart. But yet, I would my Maiſter
had Miſtris Anne, or I would M. Slender had her: or (in
ſooth) I would M. Fenton had her; I will do what I can
for them all three, for ſo I haue promiſd, and Ile bee as
good as my word, but ſpeciouſly for M. Fenton. Well, I
muſt of another errand to Sir Iohn Falſtaffe from my two
Miſtreſſes: what a beaſt am I to ſlacke it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Bardolfe I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Go, fetch me a quart of Sacke, put a toſt in’t.
Haue I liu’d to be carried in a Basket like a barrow of
butchers Offall? and to be throwne in the Thames? Wel,
if I be ſeru’d ſuch another tricke, Ile haue my braines
‘tane out and butter’d, and giue them to a dogge for a
New-yeares gift. The rogues ſlighted me into the riuer
with as little remorſe, as they would haue drown’de a
blinde bitches Puppies, fifteene i’th litter: and you may
know by my ſize, that I haue a kinde of alacrity in ſink-
ing: if the bottome were as deepe as hell, I ſhold down.
I had beene drown’d, but that the ſhore was ſheluy and
ſhallow: a death that I abhorre: for the water ſwelles a
man; and what a thing ſhould I haue beene, when I
had beene ſwel’d? I ſhould haue beene a Mountaine of
Mummie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Here’s M. Quickly Sir to ſpeake with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, let me poure in ſome Sack to the Thames
water: for my bellies as cold as if I had ſwallow’d ſnow-
bals, for pilles to coole the reines. Call her in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Come in woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: By your leaue: I cry you mercy?
Giue your worſhip good morrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Take away theſe Challices:
Go, brew me a pottle of Sacke finely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bard.
SPEECH.LINE: With Egges, Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Simple of it ſelfe: Ile no Pullet-Sperſme in my
brewage. How now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry Sir, I come to your worſhip from M. Ford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Miſt. Ford? I haue had Ford enough: I was thrown
into the Ford; I haue my belly full of Ford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas the day, (good-heart) that was not her
fault: ſhe do’s ſo take on with her men; they miſtooke
their ereƈtion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: So did I mine, to build vpon a fooliſh Womans promiſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, ſhe laments Sir for it, that it would yern
your heart to ſee it: her husband goes this morning a
birding; ſhe deſires you once more to come to her, be-
tweene eight and nine: I muſt carry her word quickely,
ſhe’ll make you amends I warrant you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I will viſit her, tell her ſo: and bidde her
thinke what a man is: Let her conſider his frailety, and
then iudge of my merit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: I will tell her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Do ſo. Betweene nine and ten ſaiſt thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Eight and nine Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, be gone: I will not miſſe her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace be with you Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I meruaile I heare not of Mr Broome: he ſent me
word to ſtay within: I like his money well. Oh, heere he comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Bleſſe you Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Now M. Broome, you come to know
What hath paſt betweene me, and Fords wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: That indeed (Sir Iohn) is my busineſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: M. Broome I will not lye to you,
I was at her houſe the houre ſhe appointed me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſped you Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Very ill-fauouredly M. Broome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: How ſo ſir, did ſhe change her determination?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: No (M. Broome) but the peaking Curnuto her huſ-
band (M. Broome) dwelling in a continual larum of ielou-
ſie, coms me in the inſtant of our encounter, after we had
embraſt, kiſt, proteſted, & (as it were) ſpoke the prologue
of our Comedy: and at his heeles, a rabble of his compa-
nions, thither prouoked and inſtigated by his diſtemper,
and (forſooth) to ſerch his houſe for his wiues Loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What? While you were there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: While I was there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: For.
SPEECH.LINE: And did he ſearch for you, & could not find you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall heare. As good lucke would haue it,
comes in one Miſt. Page, giues intelligence of Fords ap-
proch: and in her inuention, and Fords wiues diſtraƈtion,
they conuey’d me into a bucke-basket.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: A Buck-basket?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes: a Buck-basket: ram’d mee in with foule
Shirts and Smockes, Socks, foule Stockings, greaſie
Napkins, that (Maſter Broome) there was the rankeſt
compound of villanous ſmell, that euer offended no-
ſtrill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: And how long lay you there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, you ſhall heare (Maſter Broome) what I
haue ſufferd, to bring this woman to euill, for your
good: Being thus cram’d in the Basket, a couple of
Fords knaues, his Hindes, were cald forth by their Mi-
ſtris, to carry mee in the name of foule Cloathes to
Datchet-lane: they tooke me on their ſhoulders: met
the iealous knaue their Maſter in the doore; who
ask’d them once or twice what they had in their Baſ-
ket? I quak’d for feare leaſt the Lunatique Knaue
would haue ſearch’d it: but Fate (ordaining he ſhould
be a Cuckold) held his hand: well, on went hee, for
a ſearch, and away went I for foule Cloathes: But
marke the ſequell (Maſter Broome) I ſuffered the pangs
of three ſeuerall deaths: Firſt, an intollerable fright,
to be deteƈted with a iealious rotten Bell-weather:
Next to be compaſs’d like a good Bilbo in the circum-
ference of a Pecke, hilt to point, heele to head. And
then to be ſtopt in like a ſtrong diſtillation with ſtink-
ing Cloathes, that fretted in their owne greaſe:
thinke of that, a man of my Kidney; thinke of that,
that am as ſubieƈt to heate as butter; a man of conti-
nuall diſſolution, and thaw: it was a miracle to ſcape
ſuffocation. And in the height of this Bath (when I
was more then halfe ſtew’d in greaſe (like a Dutch-
diſh) to be throwne into the Thames, and
coold, glowing-hot, in that ſerge like a Horſe-
shoo; thinke of that; hiſſing hot: thinke of that (Maſter
Broome.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: In good ſadneſſe Sir, I am ſorry, that for my ſake
you haue ſufferd all this.
My ſuite then is deſperate: You’ll vndertake her no
more?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Maſter Broome: I will be throwne into Etna,
as I haue beene into Thames, ere I will leaue her thus;
her Husband is this morning gone a Birding: I
haue receiued from her another ambaſſie of mee-
ting: ‘twixt eight and nine is the houre (Maſter
Broome.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis paſt eight already Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it? I will then addreſſe mee to my appoint-
ment: Come to mee at your conuenient leiſure, and
you ſhall know how I ſpeede: and the concluſion
ſhall be crowned with your enioying her: adiew: you
ſhall haue her (Maſter Broome) Maſter Broome, you ſhall
cuckold Ford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Hum: ha? Is this a viſion? Is this a dreame?
doe I ſleepe? Maſter Ford awake, awake Maſter Ford:
ther’s a hole made in your beſt coate (Maſter Ford:) this
‘tis to be married; this ‘tis to haue Lynnen, and Buck-
baskets: Well, I will proclaime my ſelfe what I am:
I will now take the Leacher: hee is at my houſe: hee
cannot ſcape me: ‘tis impoſſible hee ſhould: hee can-
not creepe into a halfe-penny purſe, nor into a Pepper-
Boxe: But leaſt the Diuell that guides him, ſhould
aide him, I will ſearch impoſſible places: though
what I am, I cannot auoide; yet to be what I would
not, ſhall not make me tame: If I haue hornes, to make
one mad, let the prouerbe goe with me, Ile be horne-
mad.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Miſtris Page, Quickly, William, Euans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Is he at M. Fords already think’ſt thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Sure he is by this; or will be preſently; but
truely he is very couragious mad, about his throwing
into the water. Miſtris Ford deſires you to come ſo-
dainely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile be with her by and by: Ile but bring
my yong-man here to Schoole: looke where his Maſter
comes; ‘tis a playing day I ſee: how now Sir Hugh, no
Schoole to day?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: No: Maſter Slender is let the Boyes leaue to play.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Bleſſing of his heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Hugh, my husband ſaies my ſonne pro-
fits nothing in the world at his Booke: I pray you aske
him ſome queſtions in his Accidence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: Come hither William; hold vp your head; come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Come-on Sirha; hold vp your head; an-
ſwere your Maſter, be not afraid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: William, how many Numbers is in Nownes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: Two.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Truely, I thought there had bin one Number
more, becauſe they ſay od’s-Nownes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, your tatlings. What is (FaireFaire) William?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: Pulcher.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Powlcats? there are fairer things then Powlcats,
ſure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: You are a very ſimplicity o’man: I pray you
peace. What is (Lapis) William?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: A Stone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: And what is a Stone (William?)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: A Peeble.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: No; it is Lapis: I pray you remember in your
praine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: Lapis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: That is a good William: what is he (William) that
do’s lend Articles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: Articles are borrowed of the Pronoune; and be
thus declined. Singulariter nominatiuo hic, hac, hoc.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: Nominatiuo hig, hag, hog: pray you marke: geni-
tiuo huius: Well: what is your Accuſatiue-caſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you haue your remembrance (childe) Ac-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang-hog, is latten for Bacon, I warrant you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: Leaue your prables (o’man) What is the Foca-
tiue caſe (William?)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: Remember William, Focatiue, is caret.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: And that’s a good roote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: O’man, forbeare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: What is your Genitiue caſe plurall (William?)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: Genitiue case?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Vengeance of Ginyes caſe; fie on her; neuer
name her (childe) if ſhe be a whore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: For ſhame o’man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: You doe ill to teach the childe ſuch words: hee
teaches him to hic, and to hac; which they’ll doe faſt
enough of themſelues, and to call horum; fie vpon you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: O’man, art thou Lunatics? Haſt thou no vn-
derſtandings for thy Caſes, & the numbers of the Gen-
ders? Thou art as fooliſh Chriſtian creatures, as I would
deſires.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mi.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Pre’thee hold thy peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: Shew me now (William) ſome declenſions of your
Pronounes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Will.
SPEECH.LINE: Forſooth, I haue forgot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: It is Qui, que, quod; if you forget your Quies,
your Ques, and your Quods, you muſt be preeches: Goe
your waies and play, go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: He is a better ſcholler then I thought he was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: He is a good ſprag-memory: Farewel Mis. Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Adieu good Sir Hugh:
Get you home boy, Come we ſtay too long.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Falſtoffe, Miſt. Ford, Miſt. Page, Seruants, Ford, Page, Caius, Euans, Shallow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Mi. Ford, Your ſorrow hath eaten vp my ſuffe-
rance; I ſee you are obſequious in your loue, and I pro-
feſſe requitall to a haires bredth, not onely Miſt. Ford,
in the ſimple office of loue, but in all the accuſtrement,
complement, and ceremony of it: But are you ſure of
your husband now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee’s a birding (ſweet Sir Iohn.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: What hoa, goſſip Ford: what hoa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Step into th’ chamber, Sir Iohn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: How now (sweete heart) whoſe at home
beſides your ſelfe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Why none but mine owne people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: No certainly: Speake louder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Truly, I am ſo glad you haue no body here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Why woman, your husband is in his olde
lines againe: he ſo takes on yonder with my husband, ſo
railes againſt all married mankinde; ſo curſes all Eues
daughters, of what complexion ſoeuer; and ſo buffettes
himſelfe on the for-head: crying peere-out, peere-out,
that any madneſſe I euer yet beheld, ſeem’d but tame-
neſſe, ciuility, and patience to this his diſtemper he is in
now: I am glad the fat Knight is not heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, do’s he talke of him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Of none but him, and ſweares he was ca-
ried out the laſt time hee ſearch’d for him, in a Basket:
Proteſts to my husband he is now heere, & hath drawne
him and the reſt of their company from their ſport, to
make another experiment of his ſuſpition: But I am glad
the Knight is not heere; now he ſhall ſee his owne foo-
lerie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: How neere is he Miſtris Page?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Hard by, at ſtreet end; he wil be here anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I am vndone, the Knight is heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then you are vtterly ſham’d, & hee’s
but a dead man. What a woman are you? Away with
him, away with him: Better ſhame, then murther.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Which way ſhould he go? How ſhould I
beſtow him? Shall I put him into the basket againe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: No, Ile come no more i’th Basket:
May I not go out ere he come?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas: three of Mr. Fords brothers watch
the doore with Piſtols, that none ſhall iſſue out: other-
wiſe you might ſlip away ere hee came: But what make
you heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhall I do? Ile creepe vp into the chimney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: There they alwaies vſe to diſcharge their
Birding-peeces: creepe into the Kill-hole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: He will ſeeke there on my word: Neyther
Preſſe, Coffer, Cheſt, Trunke, Well, Vault, but he hath
an abſtraƈt for the remembrance of ſuch places, and goes
to them by his Note: There is no hiding you in the
houſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile go out then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: If you goe out in your owne ſemblance,
you die Sir Iohn, vnleſſe you go out diſguiſ’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: How might we diſguiſe him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas the day I know not, there is no wo-
mans gowne bigge enough for him: otherwiſe he might
put on a hat, a muffler, and a kerchiefe, and ſo eſcape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Good hearts, deuiſe ſomething: any extremitie,
rather then a mischiefe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: My Maids Aunt the fat woman of Brain-
ford, has a gowne aboue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: On my word it will ſerue him: ſhee’s as
big as he is: and there’s her thrum’d hat, and her muffler
too: run vp Sir Iohn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Go, go, ſweet Sir Iohn: Miſtris Page and
I will looke ſome linnen for your head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Quicke, quicke, wee’le come dreſſe you
ſtraight: put on the gowne the while.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I would my husband would meete him
in this ſhape: he cannot abide the old woman of Brain-
ford; he ſweares ſhe’s a witch, forbad her my houſe, and
hath threatned to beate her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauen guide him to thy husbands cud-
gell: and the diuell guide his cudgell afterwards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: But is my husband comming?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I in good ſadneſſe is he, and talkes of the
basket too, howſoeuer he hath had intelligence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee’l try that: for Ile appoint my men to
carry the basket againe, to meete him at the doore with
it, as they did laſt time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but hee’l be heere preſently: let’s go
dreſſe him like the witch of Brainford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile firſt direƈt my men, what they
ſhall doe with the basket: Goe vp, Ile bring linnen for
him ſtraight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang him diſhoneſt Varlet,
We cannot miſuſe enough:
We’ll leaue a proofe by that which we will doo,
Wiues may be merry, and yet honeſt too:
We do not aƈte that often, ieſt, and laugh,
‘Tis old, but true, Still Swine eats all the draugh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Go Sirs, take the basket againe on your
ſhoulders: your Maſter is hard at doore: if hee bid you
ſet it downe, obey him: quickly, diſpatch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1 Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, take it vp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2 Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray heauen it be not full of Knight againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1 Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: I hope not, I had liefe as beare ſo much lead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I, but if it proue true (Mr. Page) haue you any
way then to vnfoole me againe. Set downe the basket
villaine: ſome body call my wife: Youth in a basket:
Oh you Panderly Raſcals, there’s a knot: a gin, a packe,
a conſpiracie againſt me: Now ſhall the diuel be ſham’d.
What wife I ſay: Come, come forth: behold what ho-
neſt cloathes you ſend forth to bleaching.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, this paſſes M. Ford: you are not to goe
looſe any longer, you muſt be pinnion’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, this is Lunaticks: this is madde, as a
mad dogge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shall.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed M. Ford, this is not well indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: So ſay I too Sir, come hither Miſtris Ford, Mi-
ſtris Ford, the honeſt woman, the modeſt wife, the vertu-
ous creature, that hath the iealious foole to her husband:
I ſuſpeƈt without cauſe (Miſtris) do I?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauen be my witneſſe you doe, if you
ſuspeƈt me in any diſhoneſty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſaid Brazon-face, hold it out: Come forth
ſirrah.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: This paſſes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you not aſham’d, let the cloths alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall finde you anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis vnreaſonable; will you take vp your wiues
cloathes? Come, away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Empty the basket I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Why man, why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Maſter Page, as I am a man, there was one con-
uay’d out of my houſe yeſterday in this basket: why
may not he be there againe, in my houſe I am ſure he is:
my Intelligence is true, my iealouſie is reaſonable, pluck
me out all the linnen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: If you find a man there, he ſhall dye a Fleas
death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Heer’s no man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: By my fidelity this is not well Mr. Ford: This
wrongs you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: Mr Ford, you muſt pray, and not follow the
imaginations of your owne heart: this is iealouſies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, hee’s not heere I ſeeke for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: No, nor no where elſe but in your braine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Helpe to ſearch my houſe this one time: if I find
not what I ſeeke, ſhew no colour for my extremity: Let
me for euer be your Table-ſport: Let them ſay of me, as
iealous as Ford, that ſearch’d a hollow Wall-nut for his
wiues Lemman. Satisfie me once more, once more ſerch
with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What hoa (Miſtris Page,) come you and
the old woman downe: my husband will come into the
Chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Old woman? what old womans that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Why it is my maids Aunt of Brainford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: A witch, a Queane, an olde couzening queane:
Haue I not forbid her my houſe. She comes of errands
do’s ſhe? We are ſimple men, wee doe not know what’s
brought to paſſe vnder the profeſſion of Fortune-telling.
She workes by Charmes, by Spels, by th’ Figure, & ſuch
dawbry as this is, beyond our Element: wee know no-
thing. Come downe you Witch, you Hagge you, come
downe I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, good ſweet husband, good Gentle-
men, let him ſtrike the old woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Come mother Prat, Come giue me your
hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile Prat-her: Out of my doore, you Witch,
you Ragge, you Baggage, you Poulcat, you Runnion,
out, out: Ile coniure you, Ile fortune-tell you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you not aſham’d?
I thinke you haue kill’d the poore woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay he will do it, ‘tis a goodly credite
for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang her witch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: By yea, and no, I thinke the o’man is a witch in-
deede: I like not when a o’man has a great peard; I ſpie
a great peard vnder his muffler.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you follow Gentlemen, I beſeech you fol-
low: ſee but the iſſue of my iealouſie: If I cry out thus
vpon no traile, neuer truſt me when I open againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Let’s obey his humour a little further:
Come Gentlemen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Truſt me he beate him moſt pittifully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay by th’ Maſſe that he did not: he beate
him moſt vnpittifully, me thought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile haue the cudgell hallow’d, and hung
ore the Altar, it hath done meritorious ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What thinke you? May we with the war-
rant of woman hood, and the witneſſe of a good conſci-
ence, purſue him with any further reuenge?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſpirit of wantonneſſe is ſure ſcar’d out
of him, if the diuell haue him not in fee-ſimple, with
fine and recouery, he will neuer (I thinke) in the way of
waſte, attempt vs againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall we tell our husbands how wee haue
ſeru’d him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, by all meanes: if it be but to ſcrape
the figures out of your husbands braines: if they can find
in their hearts, the poore vnuertuous fat Knight ſhall be
any further affliƈted, wee two will ſtill bee the mini-
ſters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile warrant, they’l haue him publiquely
ſham’d, and me thinkes there would be no period to the
ieſt, ſhould he not be publikely ſham’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, to the Forge with it, then ſhape it:
I would not haue things coole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, the Germane deſires to haue three of your
horſes: the Duke himſelfe will be to morrow at Court,
and they are going to meet him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: What Duke ſhould that be comes ſo ſecretly?
I heare not of him in the Court: let mee ſpeake with the
Gentlemen, they ſpeake Engliſh?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: I Sir? Ile call him to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſhall haue my horſes, but Ile make them
pay: Ile ſauce them, they haue had my houſes a week at
commaund: I haue turn’d away my other gueſts, they
muſt come off, Ile ſawce them, come.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Page, Ford, Miſtris Page, Miſtris Ford, and Euans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis one of the beſt diſcretions of a o’man as e-
ver I did looke vpon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: And did he ſend you both theſe Letters at an
instant?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Within a quarter of an houre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon me (wife) henceforth do what ý wilt:
I rather will ſuſpect the Sunne with gold,
Then thee with wantonnes: Now doth thy honor ſtand
(In him that was of late an Heretike)
As firme as faith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis well, ‘tis well, no more:
Be not as extreme in ſubmiſſion, as in offence,
But let our plot go forward: Let our wiues
Yet once againe (to make vs publike ſport)
Appoint a meeting with this old fat-fellow,
Where we may take him, and diſgrace him for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: There is no better way then that they ſpoke of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: How? to ſend him word they’ll meete him in
the Parke at midnight? Fie, fie, he’ll neuer come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſay he has bin throwne in the Riuers: and
has bin greeuouſly peaten, as an old o’man: me-thinkes
there ſhould be terrors in him, that he ſhould not come:
Me-thinkes his fleſh is puniſh’d, hee ſhall haue no de-
ſires.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: So thinke I too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Deuiſe but how you’l vſe him whé he comes,
And let vs two deuiſe to bring him thether.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: There is an old tale goes, that Herne the
Hunter (ſometime a keeper heere in Windſor Forreſt)
Doth all the winter time, at ſtill midnight
Walke round about an Oake, with great rag’d-hornes,
And there he blaſts the tree, and takes the cattle,
And make milch-kine yeeld blood, and ſhakes a chaine
In a moſt hideous and dreadfull manner.
You haue heard of ſuch a Spirit, and well you know
The ſuperſtitious idle-headed-Eld
Receiu’d, and did deliuer to our age
This tale of Herne the Hunter, for a truth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Why yet there want not many that do feare
In deepe of night to walke by this Hernes Oake:
But what of this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry this is our deuiſe,
That Falſtaffe at that Oake ſhall meete with vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, let it not be doubted but he’ll come,
And in this ſhape, when you haue brought him thether,
What ſhall be done with him? What is your plot?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Pa.
SPEECH.LINE: That likewiſe haue we thoght vpon: & thus:
Nan Page (my daughter) and my little ſonne,
And three or foure more of their growth, wee’l dreſſe
Like Vrchins, Ouphes, and Fairies, greene and white,
With rounds of waxen Tapers on their heads,
And rattles in their hands; vpon a ſodaine,
As Falſtaffe, ſhe, and I, are newly met,
Let them from forth a ſaw-pit ruſh at once
With ſome diffuſed ſong: Vpon their ſight
We two, in great amazedneſſe will flye:
Then let them all encircle him about,
And Fairy-like to pinch the vncleane Knight;
And aske him why that houre of Fairy Reuell,
In their ſo ſacred pathes, he dares to tread
In ſhape prophane.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: And till he tell the truth,
Let the ſuppoſed Fairies pinch him, ſound,
And burne him with their Tapers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: The truth being knowne,
We’ll all present our ſelues; diſ-horne the ſpirit,
And mocke him home to Windſor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: The children muſt
Be praƈtiſ’d well to this, or they’ll neu’r doo’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: I will teach the children their behauiours: and I
will be like a Iacke-an-Apes alſo, to burne the Knight
with my Taber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: That will be excellent,
Ile go buy them vizards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: My Nan ſhall be the Queene of all the
Fairies, finely attired in a robe of white.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: That ſilke will I go buy, and in that time
Shall M. Slender ſteale my Nan away,
And marry her at Eaton: go, ſend to Falſtaffe ſtraight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, Ile to him againe in name of Broome,
Hee’l tell me all his purpoſe: ſure hee’l come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Feare not you that: Go get vs properties
And tricking for our Fayries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: Let vs about it,
It is admirable pleaſures, and ferry honeſt knaueries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſ.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Go Miſt. Ford,
Send quickly to Sir Iohn, to know his minde:
Ile to the Doƈtor, he hath my good will,
And none but he to marry with Nan Page:
That Slender (though well landed) is an Ideot:
And he, my husband beſt of all affeƈts:
The Doƈtor is well monied, and his friends
Potent at Court: he, none but he ſhall haue her,
Though twenty thouſand worthier come to craue her.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Hoſt, Simple, Falſtaffe, Bardolfe, Euans, Caius, Quickly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: What wouldſt thou haue? (Boore) what? (thick
skin) ſpeake, breathe, diſcuſſe: breefe, ſhort, quicke,
ſnap.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simp.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry Sir, I come to ſpeake with Sir Iohn Fal-
ſtaffe from M. Slender.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: There’s his Chamber, his Houſe, his Caſtle,
his ſtanding-bed and truckle-bed: ‘tis painted about
with the ſtory of the Prodigall, freſh and new: go, knock
and call: hee’l ſpeake like an Anthropophaginian vnto
thee: Knocke I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simp.
SPEECH.LINE: There’s an olde woman, a fat woman gone vp
into his chamber: Ile be ſo bold as ſtay Sir till ſhe come
downe: I come to ſpeake with her indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha? A fat woman? The Knight may be robb’d:
Ile call. Bully-Knight, Bully Sir Iohn: ſpeake from thy
Lungs Military: Art thou there? It is thine Hoſt, thine
Epheſian cals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, mine Hoſt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Here’s a Bohemian-Tartar taries the comming
downe of thy fat-woman: Let her deſcend (Bully) let
her deſcend: my Chambers are honourable: Fie, priua-
cy? Fie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: There was (mine Hoſt) an old-fat-woman euen
now with me, but ſhe’s gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simp.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you Sir, was’t not the Wiſe-woman of
Brainford?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I marry was it (Muſſel-ſhell) what would you
with her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simp.
SPEECH.LINE: My Maſter (Sir) my maſter Slender, ſent to her
ſeeing her go thorough the ſtreets, to know (Sir) whe-
ther one Nim (Sir) that beguil’d him of a chaine, had the
chaine, or no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſpake with the old woman about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim.
SPEECH.LINE: And what ſayes ſhe, I pray Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry ſhee ſayes, that the very ſame man that
beguil’d Maſter Slender of his Chaine, cozon’d him of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simp.
SPEECH.LINE: I would I could haue ſpoken with the Woman
her ſelfe, I had other things to haue ſpoken with her
too, from him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: What are they? let vs know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: I: come: quicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I may not conceale them (Sir.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Conceale them, or thou di’ſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſir, they were nothing but about Miſtris
Anne Page, to know if it were my Maſters fortune to
haue her, or no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis, ‘tis his fortune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim.
SPEECH.LINE: What Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: To haue her, or no: goe; ſay the woman told
me ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim.
SPEECH.LINE: May I be bold to ſay ſo Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I Sir: like who more bold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke your worſhip: I ſhall make my Maſter
glad with theſe tydings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art clearkly: thou art clearkly (Sir Iohn)
was there a wiſe woman with thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I that there was (mine Hoſt) one that hath taught
me more wit, then euer I learn’d before in my life: and
I paid nothing for it neither, but was paid for my lear-
ning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Out alas (Sir) cozonage: meere cozonage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Where be my horſes? ſpeake well of them var-
letto.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Run away with the cozoners: for ſo ſoone as
I came beyond Eaton, they threw me off, from behinde
one of them, in a ſlough of myre; and ſet ſpurres, and
away; like three Germane-diuels; three Doƈtor Fau-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: They are gone but to meete the Duke (villaine)
doe not ſay they be fled: Germanes are honeſt men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is mine Hoſt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: What is the matter Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue a care of your entertainments: there is a
friend of mine come to Towne, tels mee there is three
Cozen-Iermans, that has cozend all the Hoſts of Readins,
of Maidenhead; of Cole-brooke, of horſes and money: I
tell you for good will (looke you) you are wiſe, and full
of gibes, and vlouting-ſtocks: and ‘tis not conuenient
you ſhould be cozoned. Fare you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Ver’ is mine Hoſt de Iarteere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Here (Maſter Doƈtor) in perplexitie, and doubt-
full delemma.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot tell vat is dat: but it is tell-a-me, dat
you make grand preparation for a Duke de Iamanie: by
my trot: der is no Duke that the Court is know, to
come: I tell you for good will: adieu.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Huy and cry, (villaine) goe: aſſiſt me Knight, I
am vndone: fly, run: huy, and cry (villaine) I am vn-
done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I would all the world might be cozond, for I
haue beene cozond and beaten too: if it ſhould come
to the eare of the Court, how I haue beene transformed;
and how my transformation hath beene waſhd, and
cudgeld, they would melt mee out of my fat drop by
drop, and liquor Fiſhermens-boots with me: I warrant
they would whip me with their fine wits, till I were as
creſt-falne as a dride-peare: I neuer proſper’d, ſince I
forſwore my ſelfe at Primero: well, if my winde were
but long enough; I would repent: Now? Whence come
you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: From the two parties forſooth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: The Diuell take one partie, and his Dam the
other: and ſo they ſhall be both beſtowed; I haue ſuf-
fer’d more for their ſakes; more then the villanous in-
conſtancy of mans diſpoſition is able to beare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: And haue not they ſuffer’d? Yes, I warrant; ſpe-
ciouſly one of them; Miſtris Ford (good heart) is beaten
blacke and blew, that you cannot ſee a white ſpot about
her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: What tell’ſt thou mee of blacke, and blew? I
was beaten my ſelfe into all the colours of the Raine-
bow: and I was like to be apprehended for the Witch
of Braineford, but that my admirable dexteritie of wit,
my counterfeiting the aƈtion of an old woman deliuer’d
me, the knaue Conſtable had ſet me ith’ Stocks, ith’ com-
mon Stocks, for a Witch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir: let me ſpeake with you in your Chamber,
you ſhall heare how things goe, and (I warrant) to your
content: here is a Letter will ſay ſomewhat: (good-
hearts) what a-doe here is to bring you together? Sure,
one of you do’s not ſerue heauen well, that you are ſo
croſſ’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Come vp into my Chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Maſter Fenton, talke not to mee, my minde is
heauy: I will giue ouer all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet heare me ſpeake: aſſiſt me in my purpoſe,
And (as I am a gentleman) ile giue thee
A hundred pound in gold, more then your loſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: I will heare you (Maſter Fenton) and I will (at
the leaſt) keepe your counſell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: From time to time, I haue acquainted you
With the deare loue I beare to faire Anne Page,
Who, mutually, hath anſwer’d my affeƈtion,
(So farre forth, as her ſelfe might be her chooſer)
Euen to my wiſh; I haue a letter from her
Of ſuch contents, as you will wonder at;
The mirth whereof, ſo larded with my matter,
That neither (ſingly) can be manifeſted
Without the ſhew of both: fat Falſtaffe
Hath a great Scene; the image of the ieſt
Ile ſhow you here at large (harke good mine Hoſt:)
To night at Hernes-Oke, iuſt ‘twixt twelue and one,
Muſt my ſweet Nan preſent the Faerie-Queene:
The purpoſe why, is here: in which diſguiſe
While other Ieſts are ſomething ranke on foote,
Her father hath commanded her to ſlip
Away with Slender, and with him, at Eaton
Immediately to Marry: She hath conſented: Now Sir,
Her Mother, (euen ſtrong againſt that match
And firme for Doƈtor Caius) hath appointed
That he ſhall likewiſe ſhuffle her away,
While other ſports are tasking of their mindes,
And at the Deanry, where a Prieſt attends
Strait marry her: to this her Mothers plot
She ſeemingly obedient) likewiſe hath
Made promiſe to the Doƈtor: Now, thus it reſts,
Her Father meanes ſhe ſhall be all in white;
And in that habit, when Slender ſees his time
To take her by the hand, and bid her goe,
She ſhall goe with him: her Mother hath intended
(The better to deuote her to the Doƈtor;
For they muſt all be mask’d, and vizarded)
That quaint in greene, ſhe ſhall be looſe en-roab’d,
With Ribonds-pendant, flaring ‘bout her head;
And when the Doƈtor ſpies his vantage ripe,
To pinch her by the hand, and on that token,
The maid hath giuen conſent to go with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Which meanes ſhe to deceiue? Father, or Mo-
ther.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: Both (my good Hoſt) to go along with me:
And heere it reſts, that you’l procure the Vicar
To ſtay for me at Church, ‘twixt twelue, and one,
And in the lawfull name of marrying,
To giue our hearts vnited ceremony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, husband your deuice; Ile to the Vicar,
Bring you the Maid, you ſhall not lacke a Prieſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: So ſhall I euermore be bound to thee;
Besides, Ile make a preſent recompence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Pre’thee no more pratling: go, Ile hold, this is
the third time: I hope good lucke lies in odde numbers:
Away, go, they ſay there is Diuinity in odde Numbers,
either in natiuity, chance, or death: away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile prouide you a chaine, and Ile do what I can
to get you a paire of hornes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fall.
SPEECH.LINE: Away I ſay, time weares, hold vp your head &
mince. How now M. Broome? Maſter Broome, the mat-
ter will be knowne to night, or neuer. Bee you in the
Parke about midnight, at Hernes-Oake, and you ſhall
ſee wonders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Went you not to her yeſterday (Sir) as you told
me you had appointed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I went to her (Maſter Broome) as you ſee, like a
poore-old-man, but I came from her (Maſter Broome)
like a poore-old-woman; that ſame knaue (Ford hir huſ-
band) hath the fineſt mad diuell of iealouſie in him (Ma-
ſter Broome) that euer gouern’d Frenſie. I will tell you,
he beate me greeuouſly, in the ſhape of a woman: (for in
the ſhape of Man (Maſter Broome) I feare not Goliah
with a Weauers beame, becauſe I know alſo, life is a
Shuttle) I am in haſt, go along with mee, Ile tell you all
(Maſter Broome:) ſince I pluckt Geeſe, plaide Trewant,
and whipt Top, I knew not what ‘twas to be beaten, till
lately. Follow mee, Ile tell you ſtrange things of this
knaue Ford, on whom to night I will be reuenged, and I
will deliuer his wife into your hand. Follow, ſtraunge
things in hand (M. Broome) follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come: wee’ll couch i’th Caſtle-ditch,
till we ſee the light of our Fairies. Remember ſon Slen-
der, my

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I forſooth, I haue ſpoke with her, & we haue
a nay-word, how to know one another. I come to her
in white, and cry Mum; ſhe cries Budget, and by that
we know one another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shal.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s good too: But what needes either your
Mum, or her Budget? The white will decipher her well
enough. It hath ſtrooke ten a’ clocke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: The night is darke, Light and Spirits will be-
come it wel: Heauen proſper our ſport. No man means
euill but the deuill, and we ſhal know him by his hornes.
Lets away: follow me.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Miſt. Page, Miſt. Ford, Caius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Mr Doƈtor, my daughter is in green, when
you ſee your time, take her by the hand, away with her
to the Deanerie, and diſpatch it quickly: go before into
the Parke: we two muſt go together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: I know vat I haue to do, adieu.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Fare you well (Sir:) my husband will not
reioyce ſo much at the abuſe of Falſtaffe, as he will chafe
at the Doƈtors marrying my daughter: But ‘tis no mat-
ter; better a little chiding, then a great deale of heart-
breake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is Nan now? and her troop of Fai-
ries? and the Welch-deuill Herne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: They are all couch’d in a pit hard by Hernes
Oake, with obſcur’d Lights; which at the very inſtant
of Falſtaffes and our meeting, they will at once diſplay to
the night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: That cannot chooſe but amaze him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: If he be not amaz’d he will be mock’d: If
he be amaz’d, he will euery way be mock’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee’ll betray him finely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Againſt ſuch Lewdſters, and their lechery,
Thoſe that betray them, do no treachery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: The houre drawes-on: to the Oake, to the
Oake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: Trib, trib Fairies: Come, and remember your
parts: be pold (I pray you) follow me into the pit, and
when I giue the watch-‘ords, do as I pid you: Come,
come, trib, trib.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Falſtaffe, Miſtris Page, Miſtris Ford, Euans, Anne Page, Fairies, Page, Ford, Quickly, Slender, Fenton, Caius, Piſtoll.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: The Windſor-bell hath ſtroke twelue: the Mi-
nute drawes-on: Now the hot-bloodied-Gods aſſiſt me:
Remember Ioue, thou was’t a Bull for thy Europa, Loue
ſet on thy hornes. O powerfull Loue, that in ſome re-
ſpeƈts makes a Beaſt a Man: in ſom other, a Man a beaſt.
You were alſo (Iupiter) a Swan, for the loue of Leda: O
omnipotent Loue, how nere the God drew to the com-
plexion of a Gooſe: a fault done firſt in the forme of a
beaſt, (O Ioue, a beaſtly fault:) and then another fault,
in the ſemblance of a Fowle, thinke on’t (Ioue) a fowle-
fault. When Gods haue hot backes, what ſhall poore
men do? For me, I am heere a Windſor Stagge, and the
fatteſt (I thinke) i’th Forreſt. Send me a coole rut-time
(Ioue) or who can blame me to piſſe my Tallow? Who
comes heere? my Doe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Iohn? Art thou there (my Deere?)
My male-Deere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: My Doe, with the blacke Scut? Let the ſkie
raine Potatoes: let it thunder, to the tune of Greene-
ſleeues, haile-kiſſing Comfits, and ſnow Eringoes: Let
there come a tempeſt of prouocation, I will ſhelter mee
heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Miſtris Page is come with me (ſweet hart.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Diuide me like a brib’d-Bucke, each a Haunch:
I will keepe my ſides to my ſelfe, my ſhoulders for the
fellow of this walke; and my hornes I bequeath your
husbands. Am I a Woodman, ha? Speake I like Herne
the Hunter? Why, now is Cupid a child of conſcience,
he makes reſtitution. As I am a true ſpirit, welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, what noiſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauen forgiue our ſinnes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhould this be?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford. M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Away, away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke the diuell wil not haue me damn’d,
Leaſt the oyle that’s in me ſhould ſet hell on fire;
He would neuer elſe croſſe me thus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Fairies blacke, gray, greene, and white,
You Moone-ſhine reuellers, and ſhades of night.
You Orphan heires of fixed deſtiny,
Attend your office, and your quality.
Crier Hob-goblyn, make the Fairy Oyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Elues, liſt your names: Silence you aiery toyes.
Cricket, to Windſor-chimnies ſhalt thou leape;
Where fires thou find’ſt vnrak’d, and hearths vnſwept,
There pinch the Maids as blew as Bill-berry,
Our radiant Queene, hates Sluts, and Sluttery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: They are Fairies, he that ſpeaks to them ſhall die,
Ile winke, and couch: No man their workes muſt eie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: Wher’s Bede? Go you, and where you find a maid
That ere ſhe ſleepe has thrice her prayers ſaid,
Raiſe vp the Organs of her fantaſie,
Sleepe ſhe as ſound as careleſſe infancie,
But thoſe as ſleepe, and thinke not on their ſins,
Pinch them armes, legs, backes, ſhoulders, ſides, & ſhins.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: About, about:
Search Windſor Caſtle (Elues) within, and out.
Strew good lucke (Ouphes) on euery ſacred roome,
That it may ſtand till the perpetuall doome,
In ſtate as wholſome, as in ſtate ‘tis fit,
Worthy the Owner, and the Owner it.
The ſeuerall Chaires of Order, looke you ſcowre
With iuyce of Balme; and euery precious flowre,
Each faire Inſtalment, Coate, and ſeu’rall Creſt,
With loyall Blazon, euermore be bleſt.
And Nightly-meadow-Fairies, looke you ſing
Like to the Garters-Compaſſe, in a ring
Th’ expreſſure that it beares: Greene let it be,
More fertile-freſh then all the Field to ſee:
And, Hony Soit Qui Mal-y-Pence, write
In Emrold-tuffes, Flowres purple, blew, and white,
Like Saphire-pearle, and rich embroiderie,
Buckled below faire Knight-hoods bending knee;
Fairies vſe Flowres for their charaƈterie.
Away, diſperſe: But till ‘tis one a clocke,
Our Dance of Cuſtome, round about the Oke
Of Herne the Hunter, let vs not forget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you lock hand in hand: your ſelues in order ſet:
And twenty glow-wormes ſhall our Lanthornes bee
To guide our Meaſure round about the Tree.
But ſtay, I ſmell a man of middle earth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauens defend me from that Welſh Fairy,
Leaſt he transforme me to a peece of Cheeſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Vilde worme, thou waſt ore-look’d euen in thy
birth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: With Triall-fire touch me his finger end:
If he be chaſte, the flame will backe deſcend
And turne him to no paine: but if he ſtart,
It is the fleſh of a corrupted hart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Piſt.
SPEECH.LINE: A triall, come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eua.
SPEECH.LINE: Come: will this wood take fire?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, oh, oh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qui.
SPEECH.LINE: Corrupt, corrupt, and tainted in deſire.
About him (Fairies) ſing a ſcornfull rime,
And as you trip, ſtill pinch him to your time.
Fie on ſinnefull phantaſie: Fie on Luſt, and Luxurie:
Luſt is but a bloudy fire, kindled with vnchaſte deſire,
Fed in heart whoſe flames aſpire,
As thoughts do blow them higher and higher.
Pinch him (Fairies) mutually: Pinch him for his villanie.
Pinch him, and burne him, and turne him about,
Till Candles, & Star-light, & Moone-ſhine be out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay do not flye, I thinke we haue watcht you
now: Will none but Herne the Hunter ſerue your
turne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you come, hold vp the ieſt no higher.
Now (good Sir Iohn) how like you Windſor wiues?
See you theſe husband? Do not theſe faire yoakes
Become the Forreſt better then the Towne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Sir, whoſe a Cuckold now?
Mr Broome, Falſtaffes a Knaue, a Cuckoldly knaue,
Heere are his hornes Maſter Broome:
And Maſter Broome, he hath enioyed nothing of Fords,
but his Buck-basket, his cudgell, and twenty pounds of
money, which muſt be paid to Mr Broome, his horſes are
arreſted for it, Mr Broome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Iohn, we haue had ill lucke: wee could
neuer meete: I will neuer take you for my Loue againe,
but I will alwayes count you my Deere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I do begin to perceiue that I am made an Aſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and an Oxe too: both the proofes are ex-
tant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: And theſe are not Fairies:
I was three or foure times in the thought they were not
Fairies, and yet the guiltineſſe of my minde, the ſodaine
ſurprize of my powers, droue the groſſeneſſe of the fop-
pery into a receiu’d beleefe, in deſpight of the teeth of
all rime and reaſon, that they were Fairies. See now
how wit may be made a Iacke-a-Lent, when ‘tis vpon ill
imployment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Iohn Falſtaffe, ſerue Got, and leaue your
deſires, and Fairies will not pinſe you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſaid Fairy Hugh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euans.
SPEECH.LINE: And leaue you your iealouzies too, I pray
you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: I will neuer miſtruſt my wife againe, till thou
art able to woo her in good Engliſh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue I laid my braine in the Sun, and dri’de it,
that it wants matter to preuent ſo groſſe ore-reaching as
this? Am I ridden with a Welch Goate too? Shal I haue
a Coxcombe of Frize? Tis time I were choak’d with a
peece of toasted Cheeſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eu.
SPEECH.LINE: Seeſe is not good to giue putter; your belly is al
putter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Seeſe, and Putter? Haue I liu’d to ſtand at the
taunt of one that makes Fritters of Engliſh? This is e-
nough to be the decay of luſt and late-walking through
the Realme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Why Sir Iohn, do you thinke though wee
would haue thruſt vertue out of our hearts by the head
and ſhoulders, and haue giuen our ſelues without ſcru-
ple to hell, that euer the deuill could haue made you our
delight?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: What, a hodge-pudding? A bag of flax?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: A puft man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Old, cold, wither’d, and of intollerable en-
trailes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: And one that is as ſlanderous as Sathan?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: And as poore as Iob?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: And as wicked as his wife?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Euan.
SPEECH.LINE: And giuen to Fornications, and to Tauernes,
and Sacke, and Wine, and Metheglins, and to drinkings
and ſwearings, and ſtarings? Pribles and prables?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I am your Theame: you haue the ſtart of
me, I am deieƈted: I am not able to anſwer the Welch
Flannell, Ignorance it ſelfe is a plummet ore me, vſe me
as you will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry Sir, wee’l bring you to Windſor to one
Mr Broome, that you haue cozon’d of money, to whom
you ſhould haue bin a Pander: ouer and aboue that you
haue ſuffer’d, I thinke, to repay that money will be a bi-
ting affliƈtion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet be cheerefull Knight: thou ſhalt eat a poſ-
ſet to night at my houſe, wher I will deſire thee to laugh
at my wife, that now laughes at thee: Tell her Mr Slen-
der hath married her daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Doƈtors doubt that;
If Anne Page be my daughter, ſhe is (by this) Doƈtour
Caius wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Whoa hoe, hoe, Father Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Sonne? How now? How now Sonne,
Haue you diſpatch’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: Diſpatch’d? Ile make the beſt in Gloſterſhire
know on’t: would I were hang’d la, elſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Of what ſonne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I came yonder at Eaton to marry Miſtris Anne
Page, and ſhe’s a great lubberly boy. If it had not bene
i’th Church, I would haue ſwing’d him, or hee ſhould
haue ſwing’d me. If I did not thinke it had beene Anne
Page, would I might neuer ſtirre, and ‘tis a Poſt-maſters
Boy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon my life then, you tooke the wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: What neede you tell me that? I think ſo, when
I tooke a Boy for a Girle: If I had bene married to him,
(for all he was in womans apparrell) I would not haue
had him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Why this is your owne folly,
Did not I tell you how you ſhould know my daughter,
By her garments?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slen.
SPEECH.LINE: I went to her in greene, and cried Mum, and
ſhe cride budget, as Anne and I had appointed, and yet
it was not Anne, but a Poſt-maſters boy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Good George be not angry, I knew of
your purpoſe: turn’d my daughter into white, and in-
deede ſhe is now with the Doƈtor at the Deanrie, and
there married.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: Ver is Miſtris Page: by gar I am cozoned, I ha
married oon Garſoon, a boy; oon peſant, by gar. A boy,
it is not An Page, by gar, I am cozened.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Why? did you take her in white?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cai.
SPEECH.LINE: I bee gar, and ‘tis a boy: be gar, Ile raiſe all
Windſor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: This is ſtrange: Who hath got the right Anne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: My heart miſgiues me, here comes Mr Fenton.
How now Mr Fenton?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anne.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon good father, good my mother pardon

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Miſtris:
How chance you went not with Mr Slender?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Why went you not with Mr Doƈtor, maid?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fen.
SPEECH.LINE: You do amaze her: heare the truth of it,
You would haue married her moſt ſhamefully,
Where there was no proportion held in loue:
The truth is, ſhe and I (long ſince contraƈted)
Are now ſo ſure that nothing can diſſolue vs:
Th’ offence is holy, that ſhe hath committed,
And this deceit looſes the name of craft,
Of diſobedience, or vnduteous title,
Since therein ſhe doth euitate and ſhun
A thouſand irreligious curſed houres
Which forced marriage would haue brought vpon her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand not amaz’d, here is no remedie:
In Loue, the heauens themſelues do guide the ſtate,
Money buyes Lands, and wiues are ſold by fate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad, though you haue tane a ſpecial ſtand
to ſtrike at me, that your Arrow hath glanc’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, what remedy? Fenton, heauen giue thee
ioy, what cannot be eſchew’d, muſt be embrac’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fal.
SPEECH.LINE: When night-dogges run, all ſorts of Deere are
chac’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miſt.Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I will muſe no further: Mr Fenton,
Heauen giue you many, many merry dayes:
Good husband, let vs euery one go home,
And laugh this ſport ore by a Countrie fire,
Sir Iohn and all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford.
SPEECH.LINE: Let it be ſo (Sir Iohn:)
To Maſter Broome, you yet ſhall hold your word,
For he, to night, ſhall lye with Miſtris Ford:
